page.title: "Bhagavad Gita As It Is" trial in Russia

revision.comment: the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:"''Bhagavad Gita As It Is''" trial in Russia}} [[Image:Bhagavad-Gita As It Is (Russian).jpg|upright|thumb|alt=Color image of the Russian edition of Bhagavad Gita As It Is front cover|The Russian edition of ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'', which was put on trial in [[Tomsk]].]] The '''''Bhagavad Gita As It Is''''' '''trial in Russia''' was a trial that commenced in 2011 about banning the Russian edition of the book, ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' (1968), a translation and commentary of the [[Hindu]] holy text, ''[[Bhagavad Gita]]'', on charges of [[religious extremism]]. It contains a translation and commentary by [[A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]], founder of the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]] (ISKCON), commonly known as the Hare Krishna movement.
The trial was initiated in June 2011 in [[Tomsk, Russia]], based on an assessment of the book by scholars of [[Tomsk State University]], which concluded that Prabhupada's translations and commentaries incite religious, social, and racial intolerance. The trial caused controversy, which was reported in the Indian, Russian, and international media, as well as on social networks. The Indian government harshly criticized the proposed ban as "patently absurd" undertaking of "ignorant and misdirected or motivated individuals". The overwhelmingly wide negative response to the trial forced Russian officials to offer apologies to India, promising the necessary remedial measures to prevent the ban. The trial also sparked public protests and legal actions in India against the proposed ban and drew harsh criticism of the intellectual community in Russia, leading Russian scholars publicly denounced the perpetuation of the trial. The scholars appealed to President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and Premier [[Vladimir Putin]] for intervention and warned them of the trial's negative consequences for [[India-Russia relations]] and for Russia's international reputation.
In December 2011, the judge dismissed the court case, a decision praised by the communities both in India and Russia. On January 26, 2012, the Tomsk prosecutor's office filed an appeal against the judge's ruling, but on March 21, 2012, the appeal court dismissed it, upholding the lower court's verdict. On May 29, 2012 Tomsk region prosecutor's office decided not to challenge the appeal court's verdict. The ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial was included in the 2011 annual [[International Religious Freedom Report]] of the [[U.S. Department of State]] among instances of attempted restrictions of religious freedom by the Russian government.
==The book== {{main|Bhagavad Gita|Bhagavad Gita As It Is}} {{multiple image | width = 200 | image1 = Rajiv Gandhi meeting Russian Hare Krishna devotees in New Delhi 1989.jpg | alt1 = A black-and-whitу photo of Rajiv Gandhi holding a book and surrounded by Russian Hare Krishnas | caption1 = Indian Prime Minister [[Rajiv Gandhi]] receiving a Russian copy of the ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' from [[USSR|Soviet]] [[ISKCON|Hare Krishna]] followers. Delhi (India), 1989. | image2 = President of India Pratibha Patil with Russian Bhagavad Gita As It Is.JPG | alt2 = A color photo of the President flanked by Hare Krishna followers in robes, holding a copy of the Bhagavad Gita in Russian. | caption2 =[[President of India]] [[Pratibha Patil]] receiving a Russian copy of ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' from [[ISKCON]] leaders [[Bhakti Vijnana Goswami]] (first from left) and [[Gopal Krishna Goswami]] (third from left). New Delhi, February 2011 }} ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' is a Russian version of the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]] (ISKCON) founder [[A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]]'s translation and commentaries on the ''[[Bhagavad Gita]]'', a revered scripture for nearly one billion Hindus.<ref name=Times /> The book, a central scripture for [[ISKCON|Hare Krishna]] followers,<ref name=MoscowTimes /> was first published by the [[Bhaktivedanta Book Trust]] in 1968<ref name=HTGita1>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Settle-Gita-controversy-Krishna-tells-Russian-govt/Article1-784743.aspx|title=Settle Gita controversy, Krishna tells Russian govt|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=December 20, 2011|accessdate=December 21, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220233635/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Settle-Gita-controversy-Krishna-tells-Russian-govt/Article1-784743.aspx|archive-date=20 December 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and has been translated into 80 languages, with over 100 million copies distributed globally till date.<ref name=HTGita2>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Iskcon-If-Gita-is-banned-we-ll-intensify-protest/Article1-785039.aspx|title=Iskcon: If Gita is banned, we’ll intensify protest|last=Arora|first=Rajat|work=Hindustan Times|date=December 20, 2011|accessdate=December 21, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111221010708/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Iskcon-If-Gita-is-banned-we-ll-intensify-protest/Article1-785039.aspx|archive-date=21 December 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to scholars, the book has never been accused of fomenting extremism before.<ref name=TOI-MAU>{{cite news|last=Maurya|first=Abhai|title=Russians kick up an unholy row over holy book|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-22/india/30546077_1_expert-opinion-tomsk-state-university-iskcon|accessdate=24 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=RIR-Vanina>{{cite news|last=Vanina|first=Elena|title=Dangers of putting Gita on trial |url=http://indrus.in/articles/2011/12/23/dangers_of_putting_gita_on_trial_14075.html | accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=23 December 2011}}</ref> According to ISKCON, in 2004 and 2005 Moscow state prosecutors found no extremism in the previous edition ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', which had only slight stylistic differences from the one on trial.<ref name=TOI-BVG>{{cite news|last=Mehta|first=Mona|title=Moscow courts had dismissed Gita cases|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-28/india/30564486_1_bhaktivedanta-swami-prabhupada-bhagavad-gita-moscow-court|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=28 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=RT />
''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' was presented to a number of world leaders, including the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], who said that he "keeps a copy of the book in his office."<ref name=MoscowTimes /> Indian Ambassador to Russia [[Ajay Malhotra]] said that Prabhupada's translation of the Gita "is one of the best that you can find, because he gives you the words, the meanings and the options to understand it as it was written".<ref name=Times /> In November 2011, [[President of India]] [[Pratibha Patil]] in a message to ISKCON Russia for its 40th anniversary commended the organization for "an important role in popularising the noble and eternal message of the Srimad Bhagavad Gita and promoting spiritual harmony in many foreign lands".<ref name=TOI-temple>{{cite news|title=Facing 'ban Gita' case, Hindus build Krishna temple in Moscow|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Facing-ban-Gita-case-Hindus-build-Krishna-temple-in-Moscow/Article1-786950.aspx|accessdate=26 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=25 December 2011|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service|IANS]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225185743/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Facing-ban-Gita-case-Hindus-build-Krishna-temple-in-Moscow/Article1-786950.aspx|archive-date=25 December 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' trial follows prohibition of a number of publications by groups such as the [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and the [[Church of Scientology]].<ref name=NYT /><ref name=AP /><ref name=HTx /><ref name=IBNLx />
==Court case== The court case was filed in June 2011 by the public prosecutor of Tomsk Victor Fyodotov.<ref name=TOI-MAU /> The prosecutor based his plea on an expert analysis of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' commissioned by the [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|FSB]].<ref name=US-DS /> Its authors, three professors of [[Tomsk State University]], Sergei Avanesov, Valery Svistunov, and Valery Naumov, concluded that [[Bhaktivedanta Swami]]'s commentaries on the ''Bhagavad Gita'' contain "signs of fomenting religious hatred, denigration of human dignity on grounds of gender, race, nationality, language, origins, and religious conviction",<ref name=RIR-Vanina /><ref name=RIA-inquest>{{Cite web|title=Перевод священного писания кришнаитов проверят на экстремизм|trans-title=Translation of the sacred Krishna scriptures to be tried for extremism|url=http://www.ria.ru/inquest/20110831/427685043.html|author=[[RIA Novosti]]|language=Russian|date=31 August 2012}}</ref> claim exclusiveness of the Krishna religion,<ref name=TOI-MAU /><ref name=RIA-inquest /> use derogatory terms against those who were not devotees of Krishna,<ref name=TOI-MAU /><ref name=RIA-inquest /> and foster "social discord", "gender, race, nationality, and language" discrimination.<ref name=MoscowTimes /><ref name=RIA-inquest /> In addition to this, it was alleged to contain "calls to hostile, violent actions against a number of social and religious groups".<ref name=RIA-inquest /><ref name=newsru>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Первый зам генпрокурора, высказавшийся по суду над "Бхагавад-гитой", недостаточно информирован, считают юристы, участвовавшие в процессе|trans-title=Lawyers: First Deputy Prosecutor General insufficiently informed to comment on the trial of the "Bhagavad-gita"|url=http://www.newsru.com/religy/17feb2012/bhagavad.html|newspaper=[[NEWSru]]|date=17 February 2012|language=Russian}}</ref><ref name=newsru-tomsk>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Прокуратура Томска подала апелляцию на решение суда о "Бхагавад-гите"|trans-title=The Prosecutor's Office filed an appeal of Tomsk court's decision on the "Bhagavad Gita"|url=http://newsru.com/religy/26jan2012/tomsk.html|newspaper=[[NEWSru.com]]|date=26 January 2012|language=Russian}}</ref><ref name=gazeta>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Прокуратура Томска настаивает на экстремистском характере "Бхагавад-гиты" и подала апелляцию|trans-title=The prosecutor's office in Tomsk insists on an extremist nature "Bhagavad Gita" and filed an appeal"|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/news/lenta/2012/01/26/n_2180377.shtml|newspaper=[[Gazeta.ru]]|date=January 26, 2012|language=Russian}}</ref>
The prosecutor thus charged the book as being in violation of the Federal law № 114-ФЗ ("On countering extremist activities")<ref name=newsru /><ref name=Interfax-MID /><ref name=RIR-Interfax /> and petitioned the court to include ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' in the [[Federal List of Extremist Materials]], which would ban its printing, possession, and distribution.<ref name=MoscowTimes /> The Federal List contains over 1,000 works,<ref name=NYT /> [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]]'s ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' among them,<ref name=Times> *{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/asia/article3264291.ece|title=Anger over move to ban Hindu scripture|last=Pagnamenta|first=Robin|date=December 20, 2011|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=December 21, 2011}}{{paywall}} *{{cite news|last=Pagnamenta|first=Robin|title=Moscow targets Hindu's holy text|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/moscow-targets-hindus-holy-text/story-e6frg6so-1226227475019|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=21 December 2001|agency=[[The Times]]}}</ref><ref name=MoscowTimes>{{cite news|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/krishna-holy-book-faces-ban-in-tomsk/448803.html|title=Krishna Holy Book Faces Ban in Tomsk|author=Alexander Bratersky|date= November 28, 2011|work= [[Moscow Times]]|accessdate=December 17, 2011}}{{paywall}}</ref><ref name=Reuters /><ref name=BBC /> considered as fomenting ethnic, social, and religious hatred.<ref group="nb">Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Russian state has had problems with populist right wing movements, often organised on nationalist bases. As part of an attempt to reduce this, a [[Federal List of Extremist Materials]] is maintained. Texts such as [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]]'s ''[[Mein Kampf]]'' have been added to the list, due to their use by right wing movements. ({{cite book|title=National-Socialism, Left Patriotism, or Superimperialism? The 'Radical Right' in Russia. The radical right in central and eastern Europe since 1989.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QZr1vsDIvlUC&pg=PA257|isbn=978-0-271-01811-9|last1=Williams|first1= Christopher|last2=Hanson|first2= Stephen|series=Post-Communist Cultural Studies|year=1999|publisher=Pennsylvania State University press|location=University Park, Pennsylvania|pages=257–278|editor=Sabrina P Ramet}})</ref>
===First, second, and third hearings (August 2011)=== [[File:Судья Галина Бутенко (12 августа 2011).jpg|thumb|alt=A female judge looks into an open book|Federal Judge [[Galina Butenko]] studies a copy of the ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' during the first court hearing. August 12, 2011. ]] In the first, second, and third court hearings held on 12, 18, and 29–30 August 2011 respectively, Federal Judge Galina Butenko dismissed the assessment as inadequate and subjective after the prosecutor's experts said that their opinion in the assessment should be taken as private rather than official.<ref name=TOI-MAU /><ref name=RIR-Vanina /> According to Avanesov, the 2010 expert analysis was personally requested by [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|Federal Security]] officer Dmitry Velikotsky.<ref name=F18>{{cite news|last=Corley|first=Felix|title=RUSSIA: Has "madness" of banning religious publications been stopped?|url=http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=1652|accessdate=21 March 2012|newspaper=[[Forum 18]]|date=5 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=lenta>{{cite news|last=Попова|first=Анна|title=На поле дхармы|url=http://lenta.ru/articles/2011/12/21/bhagavadgita/|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[Lenta.ru]]|date=28 December 2011}}</ref> They also stated that the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' did not contain any extremist statements.<ref name=MoscowTimes /><ref name=TOI-MAU /> Two experts invited by the court, N. V. Serebrennikov (Tomsk) and N. N. Karpitsky (Tomsk), also rejected the written expert opinion, maintaining, that while Prabhupada's commentaries used abusive words for those who are not Krishna's devotees, the use of these words did not attempt to create a racial or religious divide, to which the Judge recalled that similarly emotionally charged statements are found in the [[Bible]], like: "Don't throw [[wikt:cast pearls before swine|pearls before swine]]".<ref name=TOI-MAU /> The court noted that, despite some claims of exclusiveness in Prabhupada's commentaries, such statements are characteristic of most religious texts and therefore posed no evidence to support the accusations made against the book.<ref name=TOI-MAU /><ref name=RIR-Vanina />
The judge consequently postponed the next hearing until December 2011, as the prosecution requested a new assessment of the book by a panel of three professors of [[Kemerovo State University]], including linguist Michael Osadchy, psychologist Sergei Dranishnikov, and religious studies expert Alexei Gorbatov.<ref name=lenta /> They were divided on the issue: two found signs of extremism in the text and one did not.<ref name=F18 /><ref name=ITAR-TASS>{{cite news|author=[[ITAR-TASS]]|script-title=ru:Томский суд отказался признать "Бхагавад-гиту" экстремистской|trans-title=Tomsk court refused to recognize the "Bhagavad Gita" as extremist|date=28 December 2011|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/c9/308329.html|language=Russian}}</ref> Following a plea by ISKCON advocate Mikhail Fralov to seek a statement of the Russian Human Rights Committee on the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' and on the right of religious minorities, the Judge agreed to hear their opinion and postponed the final verdict until December 28, 2011.<ref name=TOI-SPD>{{cite news|title=As Hindus rally, Russia court defers Gita verdict|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-20/india/30537774_1_sadhu-priya-das-iskcon-religious-movement-russia-court|archive-url=https://archive.is/20111230042909/http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-20/india/30537774_1_sadhu-priya-das-iskcon-religious-movement-russia-court|dead-url=yes|archive-date=30 December 2011|accessdate=24 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=20 December 2011|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service|IANS]]}}</ref>
===Fourth hearing and judgement (December 2011)=== {{external media | topic = [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]]'s report on the court decision | float = right | width = 238px | video1 = [http://on.rt.com/0wmg5q] }} {{wikinews|Russian court rejects move to ban Hindu scripture}} On December 28, 2011, Federal Judge Galina Butenko rejected the prosecutor's plea for a ban of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is''.<ref name=HTx>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Russia-court-rejects-ban-on-Gita/Article1-788330.aspx|title=Russian court rejects Gita ban|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=28 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610222157/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Russia-court-rejects-ban-on-Gita/Article1-788330.aspx|archive-date=10 June 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=IBNLx>{{cite news|title=Russian court rejects 'ban Gita' plea|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/russian-court-rejects-ban-gita-plea/215792-3.html|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=IBNLive|date=28 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=NDTVx>{{cite news|title=Russian court refuses to ban Gita: Report|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/russian-court-refuses-to-ban-gita-report-161516|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[NDTV]]|date=28 December 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]}}</ref> The court's resolution stated that the main criterion for classifying any text as an extremist one is the presence of calls for extremist actions and justifications for such actions, and that the propaganda of exclusiveness found in the book and criticism of political, ideological, and religious convictions is not sufficient grounds for classifying it as such.<ref name=ITAR-TASS-2>{{cite news|author=[[ITAR-TASS]]|title=Siberian court refuses to classify Bhagavad-Gita as extremist book|date=21 March 2012|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/en/c154/371816.html}}</ref>
The decision received wide coverage by the international media.<ref name=INT>*{{cite news |title = Russian Court Rejects Proposed Ban of Hindu Text |url = http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/russian-court-ban-hare-krishna-text-15243747?page=2#.Tvw6VBNOhzH |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[ABC News]] |date = 28 December 2011 |agency = [[Associated Press]] }} *{{cite news |last = Zakh |first = Dmitry |title = Russian court rejects ban on Hindu sacred text |url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gHrOJCba4pNoJkr_ZtA49WjZOP-Q?docId=CNG.4bfda62c86eb3d04eb04662280f29975.71 |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[Agence France-Presse]] |date = 28 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |last = Javed |first = Sofia |title = Russian court rejects proposed ban of Hindu text |url = http://arabnews.com/world/article555239.ece |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[Arab News]] |date = 28 December 2011 |agency = [[Associated Press]] |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111230004033/http://arabnews.com/world/article555239.ece |archive-date = 30 December 2011 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} *{{cite news |title = Russia court declares Hindu book Bhagvad Gita legal |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-16344615 |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[BBC]] |date = 28 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |title = Russian court rejects call to ban Hindu holy book |url = [[Reuters]] }} *{{cite news |last = Basu |first = Moni |title = Russian court rejects petition to ban Hindu scripture |url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/12/29/world/europe/russia-hindu-text/index.html |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[CNN]] |date = 29 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |last = Kates |first = Glenn |title = Threat of Bhagavad Gita Ban Lifted in Russia |url = http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/28/threat-of-bhagavad-gita-ban-lifted-in-russia/ |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |date = 28 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |title = Russian court rejects call to ban Bhagavad Gita |url = http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/12/28/russia-india-holybook-idINDEE7BR09B20111228?feedType=RSS&feedName=globalCoverage2 |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[Reuters]] |date = 28 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |title = Russian court rejects bid to ban Bhagavad Gita |url = http://en.ria.ru/russia/20111228/170535934.html |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[RIA Novosti]] |date = 28 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |last = Javed |first = Sofia |title = Hare Krishna text not banned by Russian court |url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/12/28/MN531MHMSQ.DTL |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date = 28 December 2011 |agency = [[Associated Press]] }} *{{cite news |last = Javed |first = Sofia |title = Russian court rejects proposed ban of Hindu text |url = http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-technology/russian-court-rejects-proposed-ban-of-hindu-text-20111229-1pd6s.html |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date = 28
