{{update|date=November 2018}} The '''Act on the Institute of National Remembrance – Commission for the Prosecution of Crimes against the Polish Nation''' ({{lang-pl|"Ustawy o Instytucie Pamięci Narodowej - Komisji Ścigania Zbrodni przeciwko Narodowi Polskiemu"}}) is a 1998 Polish law that created the [[Institute of National Remembrance]]. This [[memory laws|memory law]] was amended twice, in 2007 and 2018. The 1998 Act's Article 55 criminalizes [[historical negationism]] of crimes committed against Poles or Polish citizens by [[Nazi]] or [[Communist]] [[polities]]; of [[crimes against peace]] or [[crimes against humanity|humanity]]; of [[war crimes]]; and of [[political repression]]—all these being listed in Sections 1a and 1b of Article 1. While [[Holocaust denial]] is not ''explicitly'' mentioned, it is understood to be ''implicity'' criminalized.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xkI4DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA162|title=Memory Laws, Memory Wars: The Politics of the Past in Europe and Russia|last=Koposov|first=Nikolay|date=2017-10-12|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781108329538|language=en}} The 2007 amendment dealt with [[lustration in Poland|lustrations conducted in Poland]]. The 2018 amendment made further changes, including the addition of Article 55a, which makes it a crime to "ascribe [[Nazi crimes]] to the Polish Nation or to the Polish State"; and Article 2a, concerning crimes perpetrated against Poland or Poles by [[Ukrainian nationalists]]. The amendment caused an international controversy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/02/01/polands-senate-passes-holocaust-complicity-bill-despite-concerns-from-u-s-israel/|title=Poland’s Senate passes Holocaust complicity bill despite concerns from U.S., Israel|last=Noack|first=Rick|date=2018-02-01|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} ==1998 act== {{main|Institute of National Remembrance}} The Institute of National Remembrance was established by a Sejm Act of 18 December 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/portal/en/1/2/|title=Institute of National Remembrance – Commission for the Prosecution of Crimes against the Polish Nation|first=Institute of National|last=Remembrance|publisher=}} === Article 55 === The Act's article 55 criminalized "public denial, against the facts, of [[Nazi crimes]], [[communist crimes]], and other offenses constituting [[crimes against peace]], [[crimes against humanity]] or [[war crimes]], committed against persons of Polish nationality or against Polish citizens of other nationalities between 1 September 1939 and 31 July 1990";[[Poland|Republic of Poland]], ''Dziennik ustaw z 2016 roku, poz. 1575'' (''Register of Statutes'', 2016, item 1575) and is therefore sometimes restrictively referred to as the "law against [[Holocaust denial]].Rafal Pankowski, [http://www.nigdywiecej.org//docstation/com_docstation/20/holocaust_denial.pdf "From the lunatic fringe to academia: Holocaust denial in Poland"], in: ''Holocaust Denial: The David Irving Trial and International Revisionism'', ed. Kate Taylor, 2000 In 1999 an [[Opole University]] history professor, [[Dariusz Ratajczak]], was tried under Article 55 for his [[Holocaust denial]], was found guilty, and was sentenced to a year's probation.[[Konrad Kwiet]], [[Jürgen Matthäus]], ''Contemporary Responses to the Holocaust'', Greenwood Publishing Group, 2004, {{ISBN|0-275-97466-9}}, p.162.{{Cite web|url=http://auschwitz.org/en/museum/news/guilty-of-holocaust-denial-negligible-public-harm,227.html|title=News / Museum / Auschwitz-Birkenau|last=www.auschwitz.org|website=auschwitz.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-23}} ==2007 amendment== The 2007 amendment dealt with [[lustration in Poland|lustrations conducted in Poland]]. ==2018 amendment== {{undue weight section|date=March 2018}} {{POV section|date=June 2018}} The 2018 amendment, intended "to eliminate public misattribution to the Polish Nation or the Polish State of responsibility or co-responsibility for Nazi crimes committed by the [[German Third Reich]]", was signed into law by [[Andrzej Duda|President Andrzej Duda]] on 6 February 2018. The Amendment will come into force in 3 months after its signing. Article 55a, referred to by critics variously as the "Polish Holocaust bill", the "Poland Holocaust law", etc., has caused international controversy. Critics fear that Article 55a poses an obstacle to free discussion of historical facts about [[the Holocaust in Poland]]. Article 2a, dealing with crimes perpetrated against Poland or Poles by [[Ukrainian nationalists]], caused controversy in [[Ukraine]]. === History === A 2006 law with some of the same aims, Article 132a of the [[Polish Penal Code]], was passed in 2006, but was invalidated in 2008. After a period of lobbying, the first version of the 2018 Amendment was drafted on 17 February 2016 by [[Ministry of Justice (Poland)|Minister of Justice]] [[Zbigniew Ziobro]]. On 30 August 2016 the [[Council of Ministers (Poland)|Council of Ministers]], presided over by Prime Minister [[Beata Szydło]], forwarded the draft to the [[Sejm]]. {{cite web|url=http://legislacja.rcl.gov.pl/projekt/12282660|title=Projekt|website=legislacja.rcl.gov.pl}} The principal rationale given at the submission of the first draft was that diplomatic and public interventions against use of the misleading term "Polish death camp" and the like had proven ineffective. Therefore, it had been decided to create a legal instrument for "counteracting the falsification of Polish history and for protecting the good name of Polish citizens." Thus a new type of crime had been defined, "consisting in the attribution to Polish citizens, in public and against the facts, of the organizing, participation in, or responsibility or co-responsibility for crimes committed by Nazi Germany."{{cite web|url=http://legislacja.rcl.gov.pl/docs//2/12282660/12339392/12339393/dokument210290.pdf|title=Draft Amendment, February 17, 2016|publisher=}} This was immediately criticized internationally as an attempt to suppress discussion of crimes that had been committed during the Holocaust by Polish citizens.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/16/poland-approves-bill-outlawing-phrase-polish-death-camps |title=Poland approves bill outlawing phrase 'Polish death camps' |agency=Associated Press |date=16 August 2016 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=4 September 2016 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/08/17/obama-once-referred-to-a-polish-death-camp-in-poland-that-could-soon-be-punishable-by-3-years-in-prison/ |title=Obama once referred to a 'Polish death camp.' In Poland, that could soon be punishable by 3 years in prison. |first=Rick |last=Noack |date=17 August 2016 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=4 September 2016 }} Journalist Jerzy Haszczyński, writing in the Polish newspaper ''[[Rzeczpospolita (newspaper)|Rzeczpospolita]]'', observed that, when the expression "Polish death camp" appeared in foreign media, it "insidiously suggested that our state and our people were responsible for German crimes"; but he was not sure whom the proposed law would affect. "Almost every use of the expression that I can recall ended in a profuse apology."{{cite web |url=http://theweek.com/print/786/45744/article |title=We didn't build the death camps |first=Jerzy |last=Haszczyński |date=2 September 2016 |work=The Week |accessdate=4 September 2016 |subscription=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.rp.pl/Komentarze/308169898-Haszczynski-Watpliwa-kara-za-polskie-obozy.html |title=Wątpliwa kara za 'polskie obozy' |language=Polish |trans-title=Questionable Punishment for 'Polish Camps' |first=Jerzy |last=Haszczyński |date=16 August 2016 |work=Rzeczpospolita |accessdate=4 September 2016 }} The addition of the "ban of [[propaganda]] of Banderism" to the law (Article 2a) was spearheaded by the right-wing political movement [[Kukiz'15]].{{cite web|url=https://dorzeczy.pl/kraj/54261/Sejm-uchwalil-ustawe-o-penalizacji-banderyzmu.html|title=Sejm uchwalił ustawę o penalizacji banderyzmu|first=|last=DoRzeczy.pl|date=26 January 2018|publisher=}} Kukiz'15 submitted this addition on July 16, 2016, however it was blocked by [[Civic Platform]] and [[Law and Justice]] parties citing "the good of Polish-Ukrainian relations".[https://dorzeczy.pl/kraj/35189/Kukiz-oskarza-kierownictwo-PiS-o-uleglosc-wobec-spadkobiercow-Bandery.html "Kukiz oskarża kierownictwo PiS o uległość wobec spadkobierców Bandery"], ''[[Do Rzeczy]]'', June 11, 2017 Eventually, Article 2a was added to the bill on 25 January 2018 during the second reading.[http://www.sejm.gov.pl/sejm8.nsf/druk.xsp?nr=993-A Druk nr 993-A, "Additional Report..."], January 26, 2018 On 26 January 2018, after the bill's third reading, the Polish Parliament's lower chamber, the [[Sejm]], approved the bill,{{cite web| last1 =Parliament of Poland| first1 =| last2 =| first2 =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Ustawa z dnia 26 stycznia 2018 r. o zmianie ustawy o Instytucie Pamięci Narodowej – Komisji Ścigania Zbrodni przeciwko Narodowi Polskiemu, ustawy o grobach i cmentarzach wojennych, ustawy o muzeach oraz ustawy o odpowiedzialności podmiotów zbiorowych za czyny zabronione pod groźbą kary]| work =| publisher =Parliament of Poland| date =2018-01-29| url =http://orka.sejm.gov.pl/opinie8.nsf/nazwa/771_u/$file/771_u.pdf| format =[[PDF]]| doi =| accessdate =2018-02-02| archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/6wwITJ7NY?url=http://orka.sejm.gov.pl/opinie8.nsf/nazwa/771_u/$file/771_u.pdf| archivedate =2018-02-02| deadurl =no| df =}}{{rp|Art. 1}} which would apply to Poles as well as to foreigners. On 1 February 2018 the upper chamber, the Senate, passed the bill without amendment. On 6 February 2018 [[Andrzej Duda|President Andrzej Duda]] signed the bill into law. Some parts of the law will come into effect 14 days after its registration in ''[[Dziennik Ustaw]]'' (the Register of Statutes), with the full law coming into effect within 3 months. The law is also being referred to [[the Constitutional Tribunal of Poland]] for review of its compliance with the [[Polish Constitution]].[https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/07/europe/poland-holcaust-bill-signed-intl/index.html "Polish President signs controversial Holocaust bill into law"], ''CNN'', February 7, 2018 The bill was interpreted across Israel's political spectrum as promoting the denial of historic facts.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/27/world/middleeast/poland-holocaust-law-israel.html?mtrref=www.google.pl&gwh=60D27DE29453356F59B959F3E1193EEF&gwt=pay|title=Israel Slams ‘Baseless’ Holocaust Legislation in Poland|publisher=}} Some Israelis went so far as to accuse the Polish government of [[Holocaust denial]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/01/27/it-could-soon-be-a-crime-to-blame-poland-for-nazi-atrocities-and-israel-is-appalled/|title=Analysis {{!}} It could soon be a crime to blame Poland for Nazi atrocities, and Israel is appalled|last=Selk|first=Avi|date=2018-01-27|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}{{citeweb|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5079364,00.html|title=Israeli politicians, survivors blast Polish Holocaust law|publisher=[[Ynet]] and [[Associated Press]]|date=1 February 2018}} On February 8, 2018, the Polish government initiated an online propaganda effort supporting the law, using social media efforts to spread messages supporting the law, and broadcasting advertisements in [[Poland]] as well as [[Israel]] and the [[United States]]. Hashtags such as "#GermanDeathCamps" and "#PolishRighteousness" were spread by government accounts, and a viral video was made that is currently being spread via [[Google]], [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]]. {{citeweb|url=http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Why-is-the-Polish-government-targeting-Israeli-web-users-542375|title=Why is the Polish government targeting Israeli web users? |publisher=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|author=Hagay Hacohen|date=12 February 2018}}{{citeweb|title=YouTube Keeps Serving Me Ads for Poland's 'Holocaust Law'|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/4373m3/youtube-google-poland-holocaust-law|publisher=[[Vice]]|author=Emanuel Maiberg|date=13 February 2018}}{{citeweb|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-poland-takes-to-social-media-to-defend-its-controversial-holocaust-law-1.5803441|title=From #GermanDeathCamps to #PolishRighteous: Poland Launches Social Media Campaign to Defend Its Controversial Holocaust Law|publisher=[[Haaretz]]|author=Allison Kaplan Sommer|date=7 February 2018}} In a 24 February 2017 interview, Poland’s Justice Minister and Prosecutor-General [[Zbigniew Ziobro]] indicated that the law would not be enforced until it was cleared by the Constitutional Tribunal. This was quickly misinterpreted by Israeli media as meaning that the law had been "frozen".[http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Poland-says-controversial-Holocaust-law-isnt-frozen-543583 "POLAND SAYS CONTROVERSIAL HOLOCAUST LAW ISN'T 'FROZEN'"], ''[[Jerusalem Post]]'' According to an opinion poll conducted in February 2018, 51% of Poles opposed the 2018 amendment.http://dzieje.pl/aktualnosci/cbos-40-proc-polakow-jest-za-nowela-ustawy-o-ipn-51-proc-uwaza-ze-dezinformacji-nalezy ===Bill summary=== According to a communiqué of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], an example of such misattribution is the [["Polish death camp" controversy|use of expressions such as "Polish death camps]]". The communiqué further states:{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.pl/en/news/communique_of_the_ministry_of_foreign_affairs_on_amendment_of_the_act_on_the_institute_of_national_remembrance_|title=Communique of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on amendment of the Act on the Institute of National Remembrance|website=www.mfa.gov.pl}}
The amended act provides for a penalty, in precisely defined [circumstance]s, for the purpose of preventing intentional defamation of Poland. The final determination of a specific case will rest with the courts. The provisions of the amended act [shall] not limit freedom of research, discussion of history, or artistic activity.
The proposed law modifies a previous law relating to the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] (namely, the Act of 18 December 1998 on the – Commission for the Prosecution of Crimes against the Polish Nation (Dz.U. 1998 nr 155 poz. 1016)). The following additions caused most international controversy. *About responsibility for Nazi crimes, two additions to Article 55: :Article 55a:
1. [Anyone] who, in public and against the facts, ascribes to the Polish Nation or to the Polish State, responsibility or co-responsibility for Nazi crimes committed by the Third Reich, [as] defined in Article 6 of the [[Nuremberg Charter|Charter of the International Military Tribunal]], Annex to the Agreement for the prosecution and punishment of the major war criminals of the [[Axis powers|European Axis]], signed in London on August 8, 1945 [...], or for other offences which are crimes against peace [or] humanity or [that are] war crimes, or who otherwise grossly reduces the responsibility of the actual perpetrators of said crimes, is subject to a fine or [to] imprisonment for up to 3 years. The judgment shall be made public. 2. If a perpetrator of the act referred to in paragraph 1 has acted unintentionally, [such person] shall be subject to a fine or [[community sentence]] [([[:pl:kara ograniczenia wolności|pl]])]. 3. No offense referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 shall have been committed if the act was performed as part of artistic or scholarly activity.
:and Article 55b:
Regardless of locally binding regulations at the place at which the forbidden act took place, this law applies to Polish citizens as well as to foreigners in the case that a crime occurs as described by Articles 55 and 55a.
*About crimes of Ukrainian nationalists and Ukraininan Nazi collaborators, :the added Article 2a:
The crimes of [[Ukrainian nationalists]] and members of Ukrainian organizations collaborating with the Third German Reich, as defined in the Act, are acts committed by Ukrainian nationalists in the years 1925-1950, involving the use of violence, terror or other forms of violation of human rights, against individuals or ethnic groups. One of the crimes of Ukrainian nationalists and members of Ukrainian organizations collaborating with the Third German Reich is their involvement in the extermination of the Jewish population and genocide on citizens of the Second Polish Republic in [[Volhynia]] and Eastern [[Lesser Poland]]."
:The above text refers to [[massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia]] and to {{ill|ethnic cleansing in Eastern Lesser Poland|pl|Czystka etniczna w Małopolsce Wschodniej}} (''Note'': Eastern Galicia and {{ill|Eastern Lesser Poland|pl|Małopolska Wschodnia}} overlapped substantially, but were not coterminous: Eastern Galicia was a part of Eastern Lesser Poland annexed by [[Habsburg Austria]] to the [[Austrian Partition]] of Poland.{{pl icon}} [[Timothy Snyder]], [http://www.tygodnik.com.pl/numer/275719/snyder.htmlPięć wieków i osiem lat]; ''[[Tygodnik Powszechny]]'' – April 2002, an slightly abbreviated text of a conference presentation (Polish original). English title: "Five Centuries and Eight Years: [[Operation Vistula]] and the homogeneity of Polish society") The first addition caused international controversy and contributed to a worsening of [[Israel–Poland relations|Israel-Poland relations]]. The second addition contributed to worsening of [[Poland-Ukraine relations]].[https://wiadomosci.wp.pl/byly-minister-obrony-ukrainy-ostrzega-ponad-milion-ukraincow-moze-chwycic-za-kopie-6217366961669761a "Były minister obrony Ukrainy ostrzega: ponad milion Ukraińców może chwycić za kopie"] "Former Ukrainian Minister of Defense Warns: over a million Ukrainians may take up the cudgels." ===Controversy over Article 55a === {{main|"Polish death camp" controversy#Reactions}} Article 55a was criticized for being an obstacle to free discussions of historical facts about the [[Holocaust in Poland]]. A letter signed by many prominent persons in early February, including [[Anne Appelbaum]] and the 3rd President of Poland [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], said: "Why should the victims and witnesses of the Holocaust have to watch what they say for fear of being arrested, and will the testimony of a Jewish survivor who “feared Poles” be a punishable offence?".[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/05/polish-law-denies-reality-of-holocaust "Polish law denies reality of Holocaust"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 5, 2018 Even before being passed, the law damaged the [[Israel–Poland relations]]. Israel's Foreign Ministry director-general [[Yuval Rotem]] reported that preserving the memory of the Holocaust takes priority over international relations. He said that "Preserving the memory of the Holocaust is a matter beyond the bilateral relationship between Israel and Poland. It is a core issue cutting to the essence of the Jewish people". Israel's Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] accused Poland of Holocaust denial. [[Yair Lapid]], a member of the Israeli Parliament, wrote on Twitter: {{quote|I utterly condemn the new Polish law which tries to deny Polish complicity in the Holocaust. It was conceived in Germany but hundreds of thousands of Jews were murdered without ever meeting a German soldier. There were Polish death camps and no law can ever change that.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/yairlapid/status/957208421794709504?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&ref_url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/01/27/it-could-soon-be-a-crime-to-blame-poland-for-nazi-atrocities-and-israel-is-appalled/|title=I utterly condemn the new Polish law which tries to deny Polish complicity in the Holocaust. It was conceived in Germany but hundreds of thousands of Jews were murdered without ever meeting a German soldier. There were Polish death camps and no law can ever change that.|last=לפיד|first=יאיר|date=2018-01-27|website=@yairlapid|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}}} Dr. [[Efraim Zuroff]], head of the Israel office of the [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]], stated that, though he opposes the bill, Lapid's remarks were not factually correct: {{quote|His words were a gut reaction and they were filled with passion, but unfortunately he does not know the facts and his remarks were absurd.{{cite web|url=https://worldisraelnews.com/israeli-holocaust-experts-denounce-polish-law-whitewash-culpability/|title=Holocaust experts denounce Polish law as ‘whitewash’ of culpability|website=WIN}}{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/its-complicated-inaccuracies-plague-both-sides-of-polish-death-camps-debate/|title=It’s complicated: Inaccuracies plague both sides of ‘Polish death camps’ debate|publisher=}}}} [[Yad Vashem]] condemned the Polish bill, saying that, while "Polish death camps" as a phrase is a historic misrepresentation, the legislation is "liable to blur the historical truths regarding the assistance the Germans received from the Polish population during the Holocaust".[https://www.timesofisrael.com/decrying-new-bill-yad-vashem-says-polish-death-camps-a-misrepresentation/ Yad Vashem: Poland Holocaust law risks ‘serious distortion’ of Polish complicity], Times of Israel, 27 January 2018[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/27/israel-criticises-poland-over-draft-holocaust-legislation Israel criticises Poland over draft Holocaust legislation], Guardian, 27 January 2018 Others have pointed out that, beyond mere complicity, Poles themselves massacred Jews in the 1941 [[Jedwabne pogrom]] and in the post-war 1946 [[Kielce pogrom]], among other incidents, and that the law would outlaw mention of these events as well.[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-poland-leave-the-history-writing-to-historians-1.5768084 Analysis Poland Needs to Leave the Holocaust History Writing to Actual Historians], Haaretz, 28 January 2018[https://www.jta.org/2018/01/27/news-opinion/world/poland-wants-to-ban-the-term-polish-death-camps-there-are-historical-inaccuracies-on-both-sides-of-the-debate Poland wants to ban the term ‘Polish death camps.’ There are historical inaccuracies on both sides of the debate.], JTA, 27 January 2018[https://www.timesofisrael.com/is-new-polish-law-an-attempt-to-whitewash-its-citizens-roles-in-the-holocaust/ Is new Polish law an attempt to whitewash its citizens’ roles in the Holocaust?], Times of Israel, 18 August 2016 According to Israeli education minister [[Naftali Bennett]], "It is a historic fact that many Poles aided in the murder of Jews, handed them in, abused them, and even killed Jews during and after the Holocaust", and "It is also a historic fact that the Germans initiated, planned, and built the work and death camps in Poland. That is the truth, and no law will rewrite it." Bennett instructed schools to teach about the Polish role in the Holocaust.[https://www.timesofisrael.com/bennett-orders-more-holocaust-study-in-schools-including-polish-role-in-wwii/ Bennett orders more Holocaust study in schools, including Polish role in WWII], Times of Israel, 28 January 2018 In the U.S., Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson]] expressed "disappointment" in the bill, adding: "Enactment of this law adversely affects freedom of speech and academic inquiry."Rick Noack (6 February 2018): [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/02/06/polish-president-to-sign-holocaust-bill-despite-international-concerns/ "Polish president signs Holocaust bill, drawing rare U.S. rebuke"], ''[[Washington Post]]'' The [[Polish League Against Defamation]] filed a complaint against the Argentine newspaper [[Página/12]], a few hours after the amendment came into force. The complaint is about an article from December 2017, which illustrated the [[Jedwabne pogrom]] with a photo of the ''[[Cursed soldiers]]''.{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-israel-poland/polish-group-sues-argentine-paper-under-new-holocaust-law-idUSKCN1GF0RF|title= Polish group sues Argentine paper under new Holocaust law|author= |date= March 3, 2018|publisher= Reuters|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} According to the group, the article was "intended to harm the Polish nation and the good reputation of Polish soldiers" and "by issuing such a statement, the publisher showed great historical ignorance for which he should officially apologize to all Poles".{{cite web |url= http://www.jpost.com/International/Argentina-newspaper-first-target-of-controversial-Polish-Holocaust-law-544098|title= ARGENTINA NEWSPAPER FIRST TARGET OF CONTROVERSIAL POLISH HOLOCAUST LAW|author= EYTAN HALON|date= March 3, 2018|publisher= Jerusalem Post|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} The article had been published before the amendment of the law, and it is unclear how it would be enforced against foreign outlets.{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/05/polish-group-files-suit-against-argentina-newspaper-over-holocaust-story|title= Poland: group sues Argentinian newspaper under new Holocaust law|author= Christian Davies and Uki Goñi|date= March 5, 2018|publisher= The Guardian|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} The group did not address whether a retroactive enforcement of law was valid. Página/12 reported that they had not been formally notified, and published interviews with [[Argentine Jew]]s that escaped from Poland during the Holocaust, such as Diana Wang, president of an organization that represents Holocaust survivors and their descendants in Argentina. Other Argentine newspapers showed their support by republishing the article. The secretary for Human Rights [[Claudio Avruj]] said that "No law can limit, condemn or prevent freedom of expression or limit research". [[Jeffrey Kopstein]] of the [[University of Toronto]] and [[Jason Wittenberg]] of the [[University of California, Berkeley]], authors of the book, ''Intimate Violence: Anti-Jewish Pogroms on the Eve of the Holocaust'', about anti-Jewish violence in Poland such as the [[Szczuczyn pogrom]], opine that the purpose of the new bill "is clear: to restrict discussion of Polish complicity." They also suggest that "Poland’s current government will likely face the unpalatable prospect of enforcing an unenforceable law and denying what the mainstream scholarly community has increasingly shown to be true: Some Poles were complicit in the Holocaust.". Prof. [[Stanislaw Krajewski]] of the Warsaw University, who co-chairs the Polish Council of Christians and Jews, said that "The way the law is formulated makes it a blunt instrument for paralysing and punishing anyone you don't like", and that "the government's harsh, dismissive reaction to critics has encouraged many people to think they can now attack Jews."{{Cite news |url=http://www.thetablet.co.uk/news/8727/polish-archbishop-answers-holocaust-law-critics |title=Polish archbishop answers Holocaust law critics |last=Luxmoore |first=Jonathan |date=2018-03-14 |work=The Tablet |access-date=2018-05-12}} On 5 March 2018, in front of the Prosecutor's Office in Warsaw and Wrocław, 45 Polish citizens made public statements referring to historical events, including the [[Jedwabne pogrom]] and the [[Szczuczyn pogrom]]. The citizens claimed that they attributed responsibility for the events and alleged that their public statements constituted criminal acts under Article 55a of the amended Act of the Institute of National Memory. In the Prosecutors' offices, the citizens deposited formal written documents reporting their alleged crimes. In late March 2018, an Israeli mayor Eli Dukorsky of [[Kiryat Bialik]], who planned to deliver a speech during an event in Poland had been asked by local Polish municipal authorities to submit his speech in advance prior to its being delivered in the Israeli mayor's Polish [[sister city]], [[Radomsko]]. According to Dukorsky, subsequently Polish authorities were unwilling to accept portions of the speech that referred to Polish complicity in the Holocaust, in particular the estimate that Poles killed 200,000 Jews, and accounts from Holocaust survivors.[http://www.jpost.com/Diaspora/Holocaust-memorial-ceremony-canceled-after-Poland-censors-Israeli-speech-545479 HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL CEREMONY CANCELED AFTER POLAND CENSORS ISRAELI SPEECH], ''Jerusalem Post'', 19 March 2018.[https://forward.com/fast-forward/396912/israeli-mayor-refuses-to-deliver-remarks-in-poland-censored-under-new/ Israeli Mayor Cancels Speech In Poland After Being Censored Under Holocaust Law], ''[[The Forward]]'', 19 March 2018. According to Radomsko Mayor Jarosław Ferenc, "some of the content was historically unproven"; among other things, the claims that "Polish farmers killed 200,000 Jews during the war, and that of the six million Jews who were murdered, 200,000 were killed by Poles", were unacceptable.[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/polish-town-cancels-ceremony-with-sister-city-over-holocaust-mention-1.5917860 Polish Town Cancels Ceremony With Israeli Mayor Over Mention of Poles Murdering Jews], ''Haaretz'', 19 March 2018. Some media reports have described this event as a ''de facto'' [[censorship]], and a [[chilling effect]] related to the new law.[https://www.thejc.com/news/world/israeli-mayor-forced-to-cancel-annual-speech-in-poland-over-country-s-new-holocaust-law-1.461002 Israeli mayor forced to cancel annual speech in Poland over country’s new Holocaust law], JC, 20 Feb 2018[http://lodz.wyborcza.pl/lodz/7,35136,23164282,prezydent-radomska-nie-pozwolil-przemawiac-burmistrzowi-z-izraela.html Prezydent Radomska cenzuruje burmistrza z Izraela. Pierwsze efekty ustawy o IPN?], ''Wyborcza Lodz'', 20 March 2018. In April 2018, Polish nationalists called for the investigation of Israeli president [[Reuven Rivlin]] for his remarks at [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] in which he reportedly told Polish president [[Andrzej Duda]] "that Poland allowed the implementation of Germany's genocide" according to [[National Movement (Poland)|National Movement]] Vice President [[Krzysztof Bosak]]. According to Bosak, "it would be unacceptable if Rivlin asserted that Poland bears any responsibility for the Holocaust", with Bosak saying that his group was testing the enforcement of the new law.[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/polish-nationalists-call-to-probe-rivlin-over-holocaust-remarks-1.6011170 Polish Nationalists Call to Investigate Israeli President Rivlin Over Holocaust Remarks], Haaretz, 17 April 2018 In late June 2018 the article was amended, making the offending statements civil, instead of criminal, offences.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-44627129|title=Poland U-turn on Holocaust law|date=2018-06-27|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-GB}} The prime ministers of Poland and Israel issued a joint declaration endorsing research into the Jewish Holocaust and condemning the expression, "Polish concentration camps".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/06/27/world/europe/ap-eu-poland-holocaust-law-the-latest.html|title=The Latest: Party Head: Israel Confirms Polish View on Nazis|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en}} ===Controversy over Article 2a === {{main|Polish-Ukrainian relations}} The Amendment's passage worsened Polish-Ukrainian relations, already contentious on the questions of the prewar [[Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists]] and the wartime and postwar [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]]. [[Stepan Bandera]] and [[Roman Shukhevych]] have been considered Ukrainian national heroes in [[Ukraine]], and war criminals in Poland.{{cite web|url=https://wiadomosci.wp.pl/spor-na-linii-polska-izrael-do-grona-komentatorow-dolaczyla-ukraina-6215619519198849a|title=Spór na linii Polska-Izrael. Do grona komentatorów dołączyła Ukraina|first=oprac. Anna|last=Kozińska|date=1 February 2018|publisher=}} In Ukraine, the Amendment has been called "the Anti-[[Banderovite]] Law".{{cite web|url=https://wiadomosci.wp.pl/ukrainskie-media-o-oswiadczeniu-prezydenta-dudy-slowo-ukraina-nawet-nie-padlo-6217420400470145a|title=Ukraińskie media o oświadczeniu prezydenta Dudy: słowo Ukraina nawet nie padło|first=oprac. Violetta|last=Baran|date=6 February 2018|publisher=}}[https://dt.ua/WORLD/polski-deputati-vnochi-priynyali-zakon-pro-zaboronu-banderivskoyi-ideologiyi-267885_.html "Польські депутати вночі прийняли закон про заборону 'бандерівської ідеології' "] [Tonight Polish Parliamentaries Passed the Law on the Ban of the "Banderovite Ideology"] ''ZN.UA'', September 1, 2018, The director of the [[Ukrainian Institute of National Remembrance]], [[Volodymyr Viatrovych]], asserts that the Amendment's principal target is [[Ukrainians in Poland|Ukrainians residing in Poland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.eurointegration.com.ua/news/2018/02/1/7076941/|title=Закон про "бандеризм" спрямований проти українців у Польщі - В’ятрович|website=www.eurointegration.com.ua}} The Polish law has been compared to [[Ukrainian Law 2538-1]],{{Cite web|url=http://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/zweb2/webproc4_1?pf3511=54689|title=Офіційний портал Верховної Ради України|website=w1.c1.rada.gov.ua|access-date=2018-02-10}} passed in 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.jta.org/2018/02/06/news-opinion/world/poland-isnt-the-only-country-trying-to-police-what-can-be-said-about-the-holocaust|title=Poland isn’t the only country trying to police what can be said about the Holocaust|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|access-date=2018-02-10|language=en-us}}{{Cite news|url=http://ukraine.politicalcritique.org/2015/04/29/laws-2558-and-2538-1-on-critical-inquiry-the-holocaust-and-academic-freedom-in-ukraine/|title=Laws 2558 and 2538-1: On Critical Inquiry, the Holocaust, and Academic Freedom in Ukraine|work=Політична Критика|access-date=2018-02-10|language=en-US}} ==See also== *[[German-occupied Europe]] *[[The Holocaust in Poland]] *[[Laws against Holocaust denial#Poland|Polish law against Holocaust denial]] ==References== {{reflist|31em|refs= {{cite news | last1=Kopstein | first1=Jeffrey | last2= Wittenberg | first2= Jason | pages= | language = | title= Yes, some Poles were Nazi collaborators. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}}Four airlines, [[British Airways]], [[Qantas]], [[Air New Zealand]] and [[Virgin Australia]], have attracted criticism for controversial seating policies which [[discriminate]] against adult male passengers [[Discrimination#Sex, gender, and gender identity discrimination|on the basis of their sex]]. The companies refused to allow unaccompanied children to be seated next to adult males on their flights, leading to criticism that they regard all men as a danger to children.
The policies resulted in protests against the airlines and criticism by [[civil liberties]] and children's charities. British Airways ended its policy in August 2010 following successful [[legal action]] undertaken by Mirko Fischer.
==British Airways== In March 2001, it was revealed that [[British Airways]] had a policy of not seating adult male passengers next to [[unaccompanied minor|unaccompanied children]] (any person under the age of 15), even if the child's parents are elsewhere on the aircraft. This led to accusations that the airline considered all men to be potential [[paedophile]]s and women to be incapable of such abuse. The issue was first raised when a business executive had moved seats to be closer to two of his colleagues. A [[flight attendant]] then asked him to move because he was then sitting next to two unaccompanied children which was a breach of BA company policy. The executive said he felt humiliated as a result, stating "I felt I was being singled out and that I was being accused of something." British Airways admitted that staff were under instructions to keep men away from unaccompanied children whenever possible because of the dangers of male paedophiles.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news | last= Smith|first= Lewis | title = BA says men cannot sit with lone children| work = The Times | date = 16 March 2001 | url = http://www.vaeter-aktuell.de/english/British_Airways_-_Men_cannot_sit_with_lone_children_2001.pdf | accessdate = 5 May 2008 }}</ref>
This issue again came to prominence in 2005 following complaints by Michael Kemp who had been instructed to swap seats with his wife when on a [[GB Airways]] flight. The flight attendant informed him that for an adult male stranger to be sitting next to a child was a breach of the airline's child welfare regulations. This case was considered the more unusual because the policy was applied even though the girl's parents were on board the flight. [[Michele Elliott]], director of the children's charity [[Kidscape]] stated that the rule "is utterly absurd. It brands all men as potential [[sex offenders]]."<ref>{{cite news | title = Revealed: How BA bans men sitting next to children they don't know | work = [[Daily Mail]] | date = 4 November 2006 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=414550&in_page_id=1770 | accessdate = 21 November 2006 | location=London | first=Lucy | last=Farndon}}</ref>
In 2006 politician (and later [[London Mayor]]) [[Boris Johnson]], criticised the company after staff mistakenly attempted to separate him from his own children on a flight. He stated that those who create or defend such policies "fail to understand the terrible damage that is done by this system of presuming guilt in the entire male population just because of the tendencies of a tiny minority", linking such discrimination to the reduced number of male [[teachers]] and therefore lower [[Academic achievement|achievement in schools]]. Like others, Johnson also raised the policy's flaw in ignoring female abusers and branded airlines with such policies as "cowardly" for giving in to "[[Lunatic|loony]] hysteria."<ref>{{cite news | title = Come off it, folks: how many paedophiles can there be? | work = The Daily Telegraph | date = 9 November 2006 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3634055/Come-off-it-folks-how-many-paedophiles-can-there-be.html | accessdate = 26 Sep 2014 | location=London | first=Boris | last=Johnson}}</ref>
British Airways defended the policy, stating it had been implemented as a result of requests from customers. The company claimed that it "was responding to a fear of [[sexual assaults]]."<ref name=autogenerated1 />
===Court case=== In January 2010 businessman Mirko Fischer from [[Luxembourg]] sued the airline for sex discrimination following an incident where he was forced to change seats as a result of the policy, thus separating him from his pregnant wife. Fischer stated "I was made to feel like a [[criminal]] in front of other passengers. It was totally humiliating."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1243625/Businessman-Mirko-Fischer-sues-British-Airwars-treating-men-like-perverts.html | accessdate = 20 February 2012 | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title=Businessman sues BA 'for treating men like perverts' | first=Sophie | last=Borland | date=16 January 2010}}</ref> On 24 June 2010, Mr Fischer was successful in winning compensation from British Airways with the company sex discrimination in Mr Fischer's case. BA paid £2,161 in costs and £750 in damages which Fischer donated to child protection charities. In June 2010 BA said that the policy was under review.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/10401416.stm | work=BBC News | title=BA payout over child seat policy | date=24 June 2010}}</ref> In August 2010, it changed its policy and began seating unaccompanied children in a nondiscriminatory manner near the cabin crew.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/7957982/British-Airways-changes-discriminatory-seating-policy-for-men.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=British Airways changes 'discriminatory' seating policy for men | first=Alastair | last=Jamieson | date=21 August 2010}}</ref>
===Discontinuation=== In February 2016, British Airways announced the discontinuation of its “Unaccompanied Minor” (UM) service for children under 12 years old.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/british-airways-stops-unaccompanied-minor-service-in-bid-to-cut-costs-a6895931.html | title=British Airways stops 'Unaccompanied Minor' service in bid to cut costs | work=[[The Independent]] | date=26 February 2016 | accessdate=4 April 2016}}</ref>
==Qantas and Air New Zealand== In November 2005, it was revealed that [[Qantas]] and [[Air New Zealand]] have seating policies similar to that of British Airways. The policy came to light following an incident in 2004 when Mark Wolsay, who was seated next to a young boy on a Qantas flight in New Zealand, was asked to change seats with a female passenger. A steward informed him that "it was the airline's policy that only women were allowed to sit next to unaccompanied children".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&ObjectID=10357510|title=Ban on men sitting next to children|date=29 November 2005|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|first=Ainsley|last=Thomson}}</ref>
Mr. Wolsay, a shipping manager, stated he felt the policy "totally discriminatory", and the ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' suggested to the airline that the implication of the policy was that "it considered male passengers to be dangerous to children". New Zealand's [[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Green Party]] stated that the policy was discriminatory and reported the matter to the [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|Human Rights Commissioner]].<ref name=NZHerald>{{cite news|url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10357697 |title=Airline seating policy may breach Human Rights Acts|date=30 November 2005|work=The New Zealand Herald |first=Ainsley |last=Thomson}}</ref> On learning of the policies several protests occurred including a 22-hour tree top protest by double [[amputee]] Kevin Gill in [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]]. He stated that the policy could be the thin end of a wedge with men soon banned from sitting next to children at [[Spectator sport|sports events]] and on other forms of [[public transport]]. Gill also raised the issue of what would happen if the policy had been [[Race (classification of humans)|race]] based and targeted [[ethnic minorities]] rather than men.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707195419/http://www.fatherandchild.org.nz/News/2006/emale-feb06.pdf |title=Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2018-09-04}}</ref>
The publicity given to the issue in 2005 caused others to publicly describe their experiences. For example, [[Bethlehem, New Zealand|Bethlehem]] [[Firefighter|fire officer]] Philip Price revealed he had been forced to switch seats in 2002 on an Air New Zealand flight to [[Christchurch]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Airline seating policy outrageous first step on slippery slope | work =Bay of Plenty Times | url =http://www.bayofplentytimes.co.nz/localnews/storydisplay.cfm?thesection=localnews&storyid=3663431 | accessdate = 5 May 2008}}</ref>
Cameron Murphy, president of the [[NSW Council for Civil Liberties]], criticised the policy and stated that "there was no basis for the ban". He said it was wrong to assume that all adult males pose a danger to children.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20051130/pacific.htm |title=Ire at flight seating edict |date=30 November 2005 |publisher=Pacific News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616195216/http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20051130/pacific.htm |archivedate=16 June 2011 }}</ref> The policy has also been criticised for failing to take female abusers into consideration as well as ignoring instances of [[Child-on-child sexual abuse|children who commit sex offences]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Sex discrimination controversy | author =7:30 Report | publisher =ABC TV | url =http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/stories/s120777.htm | accessdate = 27 May 2007}}</ref> As with the British Airways case, critics such as [[Head teacher|school headmaster]] Kelvin Squire made the link between such policies and wider problems in society such as the shortage of male teachers,<ref>{{cite news | title=Airline policy reflected in society | publisher =[[RNZ]] | url =http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/423466/633882 | accessdate = 5 May 2008}}</ref> with others drawing parallels with the case of [[Rosa Parks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/node/17161|title=Commerce Secretary Defends 'Green' Investments Using Gambler's Logic|website=CNS News}}</ref>
Some have defended the policy, with [[New South Wales]] Commissioner for Children and Young People Gillian Calvert stating that there were more male sex offenders than female and thus "in the absence of any other test, it's one way in which the airline can reduce the risk of children travelling alone". She believes that the likelihood of an attack was rare but not impossible claiming "it's only a few men who do this sort of stuff, but when they do it they diminish all men". Air New Zealand spokesman David Jamieson said the company had no intention of reviewing the policy and acknowledged that it had been in place for many years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://breakingnews.iol.ie/news/?c=ireland&jp=cwmhcwgbqlmh|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617014715/http://breakingnews.iol.ie/news/?c=ireland&jp=cwmhcwgbqlmh|archivedate=2009-06-17|title=Airlines' ban on men sitting with children 'may be unlawful' - IOL|date=17 June 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
In August 2012, the controversy resurfaced when Daniel McLuskie, a nurse, had to swap seats with a female passenger on a Qantas flight after the crew noticed he was sitting next to an unrelated girl travelling alone. The person concerned felt discriminated and humiliated before the flight guests as a [[pedophile]].<ref name="Nurse 'humiliated' by Qantas policy">: ''[http://www.stuff.co.nz/travel/travel-troubles/7468866/Nurse-humiliated-by-Qantas-seating-policy Nurse 'humiliated' by Qantas policy]'', 13 August 2012, retrieved 28 April 2016</ref> A Qantas spokesman defended the policy as consistent with that of other airlines in Australia and around the globe.<ref name="Nurse 'humiliated' by Qantas policy"/>
==Virgin Australia== In 2012, it became public knowledge that [[Virgin Australia]] had also implemented this policy. Johnny McGirr, a 33-year-old firefighter from Sydney, was told to move seats by a Virgin flight attendant. When asked why, the flight attendant cited policy and told McGirr "you can't sit next to two unaccompanied minors." The attendant then asked a female passenger, "Can you please sit in this seat because he is not allowed to sit next to minors." A public backlash in Twitter prompted Virgin Australia to review its policy barring men from sitting beside unaccompanied children on flights.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Aaron|title=Should male passengers be allowed to sit next to unaccompanied children?|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/08/14/travel/unaccompanied-children-flights/index.html|website=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=19 March 2015}}</ref>

[[File:BrowserChoice.gif|thumb|right|300px|Screenshot of browser choice screen initially showing five leading browsers in a random order. The user can scroll across the page to reveal some more possible browsers in another random order.]]
'''BrowserChoice.eu''' was a [[website]] created by [[Microsoft]] in March 2010 following a decision in the [[European Union Microsoft competition case]]. The case involved legal proceedings by the [[European Union]] against Microsoft and found that, by including [[Internet Explorer]] with their market-dominant [[Microsoft Windows|Windows operating system]], Microsoft had used this dominance to create a similar market position in the [[web browser]] market. The BrowserChoice.eu website was created to allow users that had not made, or were unaware of, a choice to try other browsers, and thus comply with the [[European Commission]]'s ruling.
However, Microsoft's obligation to display the Browser Choice screen to Windows users expired in December 2014.<ref name="ars">{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2014/12/windows-browser-ballot-comes-to-an-end-as-ec-obligation-expires |title=Windows Browser Ballot comes to an end as EC obligation expires |last=Bright |first=Peter |date=18 December 2014 |work=Ars Technica |publisher=Condé Nast |accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref> The BrowserChoice.eu website was discontinued as early as the next year, showing a notice advising users to "[visit] the websites of web browser vendors directly," before going offline completely.<ref name="website">{{cite web|url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=18 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140208004146/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archivedate=8 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> {{As of|2018|November}}, the site is still offline.
==Web browser choice screen== The ''web browser choice screen'', also known as the ''web browser ballot box'', was a screen displayed in [[Internet Explorer]] that offered ten to twelve browsers in a random order.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.technet.com/b/microsoft_on_the_issues/archive/2010/02/19/the-browser-choice-screen-for-europe-what-to-expect-when-to-expect-it.aspx |title=The Browser Choice Screen for Europe: What to Expect, When to Expect It |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |last=Heiner |first=Dave |date=19 February 2010 |accessdate=24 June 2011 }}</ref>
The screen was presented only to Windows users whose default web browser is Internet Explorer. It affected the [[European Economic Area]],<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2009/dec09/12-16Statement.mspx |title=Microsoft Statement on European Commission Decision |publisher=Microsoft |date=16 December 2009 |accessdate=14 October 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217083729/http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2009/dec09/12-16Statement.mspx# |archive-date=17 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Croatia]] and [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/ie/ff606439.aspx |title=Browser Choice FAQ |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=2013-01-22 }}</ref>
A patch was made available via [[Windows Update]] to provide the screen to users. It was displayed to anyone who had not chosen another browser as their default browser.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Microsoft-liefert-Web-Browser-Auswahlfenster-ab-17-Maerz-aus-935566.html |title=Microsoft liefert Web-Browser-Auswahlfenster ab 17. März aus |publisher=heise online |language=German |date=19 February 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref>
==Browsers listed== The browser choice screen listed 10 to 12 browsers in random order; the top tier of five were immediately visible and the remaining ones could be seen by scrolling the list. The order of the browsers on the page was initially planned to be alphabetical, but after criticism a random system was used with two groups.
The first group included the five most used browsers ‒ [[Internet Explorer]], [[Mozilla Firefox]], [[Google Chrome]], [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]], and initially [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] but later [[Maxthon]] ‒ representing the four major rendering engines ([[Trident (layout engine)|Trident]], [[Gecko (layout engine)|Gecko]], [[Blink (layout engine)|Blink]] and [[WebKit]]). The second group contained less well-known browsers, also in random order: at different times this group included [[Avant Browser]], [[Comodo Dragon (web browser)|Comodo Dragon]], [[Flock (web browser)|Flock]], [[GreenBrowser]], [[K-Meleon]], [[Lunascape (web browser)|Lunascape]], [[Maxthon]], [[Rockmelt]], [[SRWare Iron]], [[Sleipnir (web browser)|Sleipnir]], and [[SlimBrowser]].
===Revisions=== The initial March 2010 list had [[Internet Explorer]], [[Mozilla Firefox|Firefox]], [[Google Chrome|Chrome]], [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]] and [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]] in the first tier, with [[Avant Browser]], [[Flock (web browser)|Flock]], [[GreenBrowser]], [[K-Meleon]], [[Maxthon]], [[Sleipnir (web browser)|Sleipnir]] and [[SlimBrowser]] in the second tier.
In August 2010 Microsoft removed GreenBrowser and Sleipnir from the choices, replacing them with [[Lunascape (web browser)|Lunascape]] and [[SRWare Iron]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822062000/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=22 August 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828094328/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=28 August 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref>
In November 2011 Microsoft reduced the number of second tier browsers from the previous seven to six. They removed Flock and SlimBrowser, but re-established Sleipnir.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103214224/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=3 November 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2013}}</ref>
In February 2012 Microsoft increased the number of second tier browsers to seven: [[Comodo Dragon (web browser)|Comodo Dragon]] and [[Rockmelt]] were added, while Sleipnir was removed again.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224114437/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=24 February 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2013}}</ref>
In August 2012 Microsoft removed Apple Safari from the first tier due to the browser's discontinuation on Windows, and replaced it with Maxthon. SlimBrowser was added back to the second tier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919182030/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=19 September 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2013}}</ref>
In February 2013 Microsoft removed SlimBrowser from the second tier and replaced it with Sleipnir.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226201610/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |archivedate=26 February 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref>
In May 2013 Microsoft removed Rockmelt from the second tier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |accessdate=30 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530112827/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archivedate=30 May 2013 }}</ref>
By May 2014 Microsoft had removed Comodo Dragon from the second tier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |accessdate=18 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516183141/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archivedate=16 May 2014}}</ref>
In September 2014 Comodo was returned to the second tier, replacing Avant Browser.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |title=Information Regarding Web Browsers |accessdate=18 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903235102/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm |archivedate=3 September 2014 }}</ref>
In December 2014 the website was discontinued and no longer lists any browsers.<ref name="ars" /><ref name="website" />

Lunascape, SRWare Iron, Comodo Dragon, Sleipnir | [https://web.archive.org/web/20140903235102/http://www.browserchoice.eu/BrowserChoice/browserchoice_en.htm] |}
==Results== Competing browsers saw their traffic increase,<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/08/technology/08browser.html |title=Microsoft Gives Rival Browsers a Lift |last=Pfanner |first=Eric |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=7 March 2010 |accessdate=7 March 2010 }}</ref> suggesting that these smaller competing developers were gaining users. However, long-term trends show browsers such as Opera and Firefox losing market share in Europe, calling into question the usefulness of the browser choice screen.<ref name="ars" />
==Criticism== The source code of the page itself came under criticism. The order of the browsers on screen was at first insufficiently random, which led to uneven distribution.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/02/22/microsoft-ballot-screen |title=How Random Is Microsoft's Random Browser Choice Screen In Europe? |publisher=TechCrunch |last=Wauters |first=Robin |date=22 February 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2010/03/coding-error-leads-to-uneven-eu-browser-ballot-distribution |title=Coding error leads to uneven EU browser ballot distribution |publisher=Ars Technica |last=Bright |first=Peter |date=2 March 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref> This was later fixed by Microsoft.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/03/09/microsoft_browser_ballot_update |title=Microsoft rejiggers EU browser ballot after complaints |publisher=[[The Register]] |last=Metz |first=Cade |date=9 March 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref>
The choice of browsers was also criticised.<ref name="bbcLimited">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8545237.stm |title=Microsoft browser ballot criticised for being 'limited' |publisher=BBC |last=Ward |first=Mark |date=3 March 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref> At the time of its inception, half of the suggested browsers use Internet Explorer's [[Trident (layout engine)|Trident]] rendering engine, thus users who choose web browsers other than Internet Explorer for the intention of avoiding it might still end up using IE's layout engine.<ref name="bbcLimited" /> This has resulted in criticism amongst the web development community even though Microsoft was adhering to the court agreement's methodology.<ref name="bbcLimited" />
Finally, the overall ability for users to access the site was criticised. [[Opera Software]] complained that the ballot screen could not be reached in some cases because of the start configuration screens of IE.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/04/03/windows_ie_browser_ballot_screen |title=Opera alerts EU to hidden Windows browser-ballot |last=Clarke |first=Gavin |date=3 April 2010 |publisher=[[The Register]] |accessdate=8 April 2010 }}</ref> In 2012 Microsoft had issues with both Windows 7 and Windows 8 no longer leading new users in the [[European Union]] to the page. The [[Windows7#Service Pack 1|Windows 7 SP1]] retail release was initially missing BrowserChoice.eu functionality, affecting 28 million computers. The error remained unpatched for 14 months, and as a result in March 2013 the European Commission fined Microsoft €561 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-21684329 |title=Microsoft fined by European Commission over web browser |publisher=BBC |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> [[Windows 8]] was also released without the browser choice screen functionality and patched several days after the release. [[Mozilla]]'s general counsel estimated that 6-9 million downloads of Firefox web browser alone were lost due to the mistake.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.zdnet.com/firefox-lost-6-9-million-downloads-in-eu-browser-choice-glitch-7000006670/ |title=Firefox lost 6-9 million downloads in EU browser choice 'glitch' |last=Whittaker |first=Zach |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |date=31 October 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/9/10/3307564/windows-8-browser-choice-europe-windows-update |title=Windows 8 browser choice update now available in Europe |last=Warren |first=Tom |publisher=[[The Verge]] |date=10 September 2012 |accessdate=6 February 2013 }}</ref>
==Petition== Makers of the second-tier browsers [[Flock (web browser)|Flock]], [[Avant Browser|Avant]], [[GreenBrowser]], [[Maxthon]], [[Sleipnir (web browser)|Sleipnir]], and [[SlimBrowser|Slim]] sent a petition to the EU to get [[Microsoft]] to add text or a graphic (rather than just the slider) indicating that there are more than five browsers.<ref>[http://flock.com/petition_to_the_european_commission.pdf Petition To The European Commission] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101030021348/http://flock.com/petition_to_the_european_commission.pdf |date=30 October 2010 }}</ref> Microsoft responded by stating: ''"We (Microsoft) do not plan on making any changes at this time."''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-30685_3-20000129-264.html |title=Minor browsers seek more prominence in Europe |publisher=CNET |last=Shankland |first=Stephen |date=5 March 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2012 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Microsoft Corp. v. Commission|European Union Microsoft competition case]] * ''[[United States v. Microsoft Corp.]]'' * [[Criticism of Microsoft]] * [[Microsoft litigation]]
