revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} This is a '''list of wrongful convictions in the United States'''. This list includes people who have been legally exonerated, including people whose convictions have been overturned and have not been retried, as well as people who have not been formally exonerated but are widely considered to be factually innocent. This list includes only exonerees or cases that already have supporting Wikipedia articles. Crime descriptions marked with an '''asterisk''' (*) indicate that the events were later determined not to be criminal acts.
==Before 1900== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of crime ! Defendant(s) ! Crime ! Location ! Sentence ! Time served ! Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |1673 |rowspan="2" |[[Thomas Cornell (settler)#Murder Trial of Thomas Cornell Jr.|Thomas Cornell Jr.]] |[[Murder]] of his mother |[[Portsmouth, Rhode Island]] |Death |Executed |No |- |colspan=5|Thomas Cornell Jr. was accused, tried, convicted and hanged for the alleged murder of his mother, Rebecca Briggs Cornell, in Portsmouth in 1673. He was convicted using [[circumstantial evidence]] as well as [[spectral evidence]], where witnesses recounted dreams involving ghosts pointing to his alleged guilt.<ref>This case and its history have been chronicled in the book ''Killed Strangely: The Death of Rebecca Cornell'' by Elaine Forman Crane.</ref> American jurisprudence was later modernized to exclude the use of apparitions and dreams as evidence in trials. |-- |-- |rowspan="2" |1692 |rowspan="2" |[[Salem witch trials]] |[[Witchcraft]]* |[[Salem, Massachusetts]], as well as other nearby towns |Death |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|The Salem witch trials were a series of hearings and prosecutions of people accused of [[witchcraft]] in [[Province of Massachusetts Bay|colonial Massachusetts]] between February 1692 and May 1693. The trials resulted in the [[execution]]s of twenty people, most of them women. Despite being generally known as the [[Salem, Massachusetts|Salem]] [[Witch trials in the early modern period|witch trials]], the preliminary hearings in 1692 were conducted in several towns in the Province of Massachusetts Bay: Salem Village (now [[Danvers, Massachusetts|Danvers]]), [[Ipswich, Massachusetts|Ipswich]], [[Andover, Massachusetts|Andover]], and Salem Town. |-- |rowspan="2" |1805, November 12 |rowspan="2" |[[Dominic Daley]] and [[James Halligan (1778–1806)|James Halligan]] |Murder of Marcus Lyon |[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] |Death |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|In November 1805, the body of a young farmer, Marcus Lyon, was found on the open road near the town of [[Wilbraham, Massachusetts]]. Irish immigrants Dominic Daley and James Halligan were traveling in the area at the time, heading for [[New Haven, Connecticut]], when they were arrested for the murder on November 12, 1805. Their captor received a reward of $500. They had a lengthy confinement, but were granted defense attorneys only 48 hours before their trial. Once the trial began, they were convicted within minutes. One of the defense attorneys said that the evidence was so flimsy it was obvious their conviction was based on outright bigotry. They were executed the next day. On [[St. Patrick's Day]] 1984, Governor [[Michael Dukakis]] of Massachusetts issued a proclamation exonerating Daley and Halligan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historic-northampton.org/daleyandhalligan/daleyandhalligan.html|title=Daley & Halligan - Historic Northampton Museum and Education Center|author=|date=|website=www.historic-northampton.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927143703/http://www.historic-northampton.org/daleyandhalligan/daleyandhalligan.html|archivedate=September 27, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1843, December 31 |rowspan="2" |[[John Gordon (Rhode Island)|John Gordon]] |Murder of Amasa Sprague |[[Knightsville, Rhode Island]] |Death |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|In 1843 Gordon was the last person [[Capital punishment in Rhode Island|executed by Rhode Island]]. His conviction and execution have been ascribed by researchers to anti-[[Roman Catholic]] and anti-Irish [[immigrant]] bias.<ref name="mckay">McKay, Scott. [http://www.projo.com/news/content/death_penalty_case_05-25-08_TCA892N_v56.2f760d1.html "Judge's old notes shed light on last execution in R.I."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628222234/http://www.projo.com/news/content/death_penalty_case_05-25-08_TCA892N_v56.2f760d1.html |date=June 28, 2011 }} ''[[Providence Journal]]''. May 25, 2008.</ref> He was convicted for the murder of Amasa Sprague, a [[Cranston, Rhode Island|Cranston]] [[textile]] factory owner. The court justices, who included Justice [[Job Durfee]], were involved in all three trials as both trial judges and the court of final appeal.<ref name="hoffman">Hoffman, Charles G. and Tess Hoffmann (1998). ''Brotherly Love: Murder and the Politics of Prejudice in Nineteenth-Century Rhode Island''. Boston: [[University of Massachusetts Press]]. {{ISBN|1-55849-163-5}}.</ref> Durfee "told the jurors to give greater weight to [[Yankee]] witnesses than Irish witnesses."<ref name="mckay"/> Rhode Island Governor [[Lincoln Chafee]] pardoned Gordon on June 29, 2011.<ref name=pardon>Erika Niedowski, [http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode_island/articles/2011/06/29/ri_governor_pardons_irish_man_hanged_in_1845/ "RI governor pardons Irish man hanged in 1845"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702114523/http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode_island/articles/2011/06/29/ri_governor_pardons_irish_man_hanged_in_1845/ |date=July 2, 2011 }}, [[Associated Press]], 2011-06-29.</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1855 |rowspan="2" |[[Chief Leschi]] |Murder of Abram Benton Moses and Joseph Miles (or Miller) |[[Olympia, Washington]] |Death by hanging |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|Leschi was a [[Nisqually people|Nisqually]] chief when the United States government attempted to relocate the tribe to reservations. Leschi protested the move, claiming the reservation designated for the Nisqually was a rocky piece of high ground unsuited to growing food and cut off from access to the river that provided salmon, the mainstay of their livelihood.<ref>{{cite book |last=Carpenter |first=Cecelia Svinth |authorlink=|title=[[They Walked Before: The Indians of Washington State]] |year=1977 |publisher=Washington State American Revolution Bicentennial Commission |location=Tacoma, Washington | pages=29 |isbn=0-917048-04-0}}</ref> Leschi traveled to the territorial capital at [[Olympia, Washington|Olympia]] to protest the terms of the treaty. He became war chief, in command of around 300 men, and led a small number of raids. Early in the conflict, Territorial militiamen Abram Benton Moses and Joseph Miles (or Miller) were killed.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Governor Stevens' Famous Pardon of Himself |journal=Washington Historical Quarterly |volume=25 |number=3 |year=1934 |url=http://journals.lib.washington.edu/index.php/WHQ/article/view/8829 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114802/http://journals.lib.washington.edu/index.php/WHQ/article/view/8829 |archivedate=August 26, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Leschi maintained his innocence. He was convicted and executed. In 2004, he was posthumously exonerated by the state. |-- |rowspan="2" |1863 |rowspan="2" |[[Chipita Rodriguez]] |Murder of John Savage |[[San Patricio, Texas]] |Death by hanging |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|Rodriguez was convicted of murdering John Savage with an ax and executed. She was posthumously exonerated in 1985.<ref name=Davies>{{cite book|last1=Davies|first1=Jennifer|title=Wrongly Convicted : Miscarriages of Justice|date=October 6, 2013|publisher=RW Press}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1872, May 5 |rowspan="2" |[[William Jackson Marion]] |Murder of John Cameron* |[[Liberty, Nebraska]] |Death by hanging |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|Marion was convicted of killing John Cameron, who left with him to work on the railroad in 1872. In 1891, four years after Marion's execution by hanging, Cameron turned up alive, explaining that he had vanished by his own volition. He had spent twenty years traveling across Mexico, Alaska, and Colorado. On March 25, 1987, Marion was pardoned posthumously by the State of Nebraska on the 100th anniversary of his hanging.<ref>{{cite news|title=1887 Hanging Remains Nebraska's Most Controversial Execution|url=http://www.netnebraska.org/article/news/1887-hanging-remains-nebraskas-most-controversial-execution|publisher=NET Nebraska|date=February 7, 2013|accessdate=May 15, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710225057/http://www.netnebraska.org/article/news/1887-hanging-remains-nebraskas-most-controversial-execution|archivedate=July 10, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1886, May 4 |rowspan="2" |[[Oscar Neebe]] |[[Haymarket affair]] |[[Chicago]], Illinois |15 years in prison |7 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Neebe was not present at the Haymarket Square on the day of the bombing, and stated that he was not aware it had happened until he was told about it the following day. He was arrested because of his association with the defendants. At trial, the evidence against Neebe was particularly weak, mostly based on his political views, his having attended socialist meetings, being associated with the newspaper, ''Arbeiter-Zeitung'', and the fact that a shotgun, a pistol and red flag were found in his home. On June 26, 1893, Illinois Governor [[John Peter Altgeld]] pardoned Neebe and two of his co-defendants, having concluded that they were innocent.<ref>[http://www.chicagohs.org/hadc/books/b06/B06.htm HADC - Reasons for pardoning Fielden, Neebe and Schwab<!-- bot-generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114121423/http://www.chicagohs.org/hadc/books/b06/B06.htm|date=November 14, 2007}} at www.chicagohs.org</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1887 |rowspan="2" |[[Charles Hudspeth (convict)|Charles Hudspeth]] |Murder of George Watkins* |[[Marion County, Arkansas]] |Death by hanging |Executed | |- |colspan=5|Hudspeth and George Watkins' wife Rebecca were arrested. After lengthy interrogation, Rebecca allegedly made a statement accusing Hudspeth of murdering Watkins to get him out of the way so they could be married. Based on Rebecca's testimony, Hudspeth was convicted and sentenced to death. He was hanged at [[Harrison, Arkansas]], on December 30, 1892. In 1893, Hudspeth's lawyer located the alleged victim, George Watkins, alive and well in [[Kansas]]. |-- |rowspan="2" |1894, August 9 |rowspan="2" |[[1894 Rock Island railroad wreck#Investigation|George Washington Davis]] |[[1894 Rock Island railroad wreck|Sabotage of Locomotive 213]], resulting in 11 deaths |[[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | |10 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Davis was convicted of causing the [[1894 Rock Island railroad wreck]], which killed eleven of thirty-three people on a passenger train traveling from [[Fairbury, Nebraska]], to [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. Some survivors claimed to have seen him holding a lantern at the site of the crash; however, there was no evidence that Davis had anything to do with the incident. In 1905, Davis was paroled by [[Governor of Nebraska|Nebraska governor]] [[John Mickey]], citing "grave doubts" as to his involvement in the crash.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://journalstar.com/special-section/epilogue/article_2e0de0cc-1fc6-11df-9c5b-001cc4c002e0.html |title=Epilogue: A forgotten mystery of death and destruction |newspaper=Lincoln Journal-Star |date=2010-02-22 |accessdate=2015-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231054209/http://journalstar.com/special-section/epilogue/article_2e0de0cc-1fc6-11df-9c5b-001cc4c002e0.html |archivedate=December 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://journalstar.com/original-story-from-death-by-fire/article_a946fcfe-1fc8-11df-80d0-001cc4c002e0.html |title=Original story from 1894: Death by fire |newspaper=Lincoln Journal-Star |date=2010-02-22 |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/article_5ab20594-a3e8-11df-8280-001cc4c03286.html |title=Historical train crash marker dedicated southwest of Lincoln |newspaper=Lincoln Journal-Star |date=2010-08-09 |accessdate=2015-05-15}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1896 |rowspan="2" |[[Jack Davis (prospector)|Jack Davis]] |Murder of Daniel Cummings and John Wilson |[[Silver City, Idaho]] |Death by hanging |6 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Davis was convicted of the [[Deep Creek murders]]. He was later pardoned following confessions by James Bower and Jeff Gray.<ref name="Lukas, pg. 288-289">{{cite book|last=Lukas|first=J. Anthony|authorlink=|title=Big Trouble: A Murder in a Small Western Town Sets Off a Struggle for the Soul of America|publisher=Simon and Schuster|series=|year=1998|doi=|isbn=978-0-684-84617-0}}</ref><ref name="Meyers, pg. 25">{{cite book|last=Myers|first=John M. |title=The Westerners: A Roundup of Pioneer Reminiscences|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|series=|year=1997 |isbn=978-0-8032-8236-0}}</ref><ref name="legendsofamerica.com">{{Cite web | title=More Idaho Treasues Just Waiting To Be Found | url=http://www.legendsofamerica.com/id-treasures6.html | accessdate=June 27, 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629001454/http://www.legendsofamerica.com/id-treasures6.html | archivedate=June 29, 2012 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> |}
==1900s== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of crime ! Defendant(s) ! Crime ! Location ! Sentence ! Time served ! Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |1900 |rowspan="2" |[[Caleb Powers]] |Murder of [[William Goebel]] |[[Frankfort, Kentucky]] | |8 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Powers was convicted of complicity in the [[assassination]] of [[Governor of Kentucky|Governor]] [[William Goebel]] in 1900. The prosecution charged that Powers was the mastermind, having a political opponent killed so that his boss, Governor [[William S. Taylor]], could stay in office. He was sentenced to [[prison]]. An [[appeals court]] overturned Powers' conviction, though Powers was tried three more times, resulting in two convictions and a [[hung jury]]. Governor [[Augustus E. Willson]] pardoned Powers in 1908. Powers had served eight years in prison. While in prison, Powers authored the book ''My Own Story'' (1905). |-- |rowspan="2" |February 11, 1906 |rowspan="2" |[[Ed Johnson (victim of lynching)|Ed Johnson]] |Rape of Nevada Taylor |[[Chattanooga, Tennessee]] |Hanging |Lynched prior to execution |Posthumously exonerated |- |colspan=5|Ed Johnson, a [[African Americans|black man]], was convicted for the [[rape]] of Nevada Taylor, a [[white Americans|white]] woman, and [[capital punishment|sentenced to death]]. Taylor's initial description of the man was very vague. She told police she didn't get a good look at him and was unsure if the assailant was black or white. After the reward was increased to $375, another man in town told police he saw Johnson at the scene, and Taylor subsequently identified Johnson as her rapist. Johnson was beaten by sheriff Joseph Shipp to extract a confession, but maintained his innocence. On March 3, 1906, Johnson appealed the conviction, alleging that his constitutional rights had been violated. Specifically, he alleged that all blacks had been excluded from the jury considering his case, and that he should have been granted a change of venue, and a continuance. He was granted a stay of execution and an appeal to the [[U.S. Supreme Court]].
The decision<!-- Which was what? --> was communicated to Shipp, who moved most prisoners to other floors of the jail and sent home all but one deputy, presumably to assist the lynch mob. Johnson was pulled from his cell by a group of white men and hanged. Following the [[lynching]], Shipp publicly blamed the Supreme Court's interference with local courts for Johnson's death.
The [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] charged Shipp, his chief jailer, and several members of the lynch mob with [[contempt of court]] on the basis that Sheriff Shipp, with full knowledge of the court's ruling, nonetheless chose willfully to ignore his duties to protect a prisoner in his care and allowed Johnson to be lynched. ''[[United States v. Shipp]]'' is the only criminal trial of the Supreme Court in its entire history. It is considered an important decision in that it affirmed the right of the Supreme Court to intervene in state criminal cases.
Shipp and several of his co-defendants were convicted and sentenced to terms from 2–3 months in federal prison.<ref name=Lief>{{cite book|last1=Lief|first1=Michael S.|title=The Devil's Advocates: Greatest Closing Arguments in Criminal Law|date=September 11, 2007|publisher=Scribner|isbn=0743246691}}</ref> |}
==1910s== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of crime ! Defendant(s) ! Crime ! Location ! Sentence ! Time served ! Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |1912 |rowspan="2" |[[Bill Wilson (convict)|Bill Wilson]] |Murder of his wife Jenny Wilson and their one-year-old daughter* |[[Blount County, Alabama]] |Life in prison |6 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Wilson was convicted of murdering his wife and their 19-month-old daughter. Bones presented in court were later discovered to be those of at least four or five people and likely indigenous. He received a formal pardon after his wife and daughter were discovered alive and living in [[Vincennes, Indiana]]. |-- |rowspan="2" |1913 |rowspan="2" |[[Thomas Griffin (farmer)|Thomas Griffin and Meeks Griffin]] |Murder of John Q. Lewis |[[Chester County, South Carolina]] |Death |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|The brothers were prominent black farmers in [[Chester County, South Carolina]], believed to be the wealthiest blacks in the area. They were convicted and executed via the [[electric chair]] in 1915 for the murder in 1913 of 75-year-old John Q. Lewis. The Griffin brothers were convicted based on the accusations of another black man, John "Monk" Stevenson, who was known to be a small-time thief. Stevenson, who was found in possession of the victim's pistol, was sentenced to life in prison in exchange for testifying against the brothers. Two other African Americans, Nelson Brice and John Crosby, were executed with the brothers for the same crime. Some in the community believed that Lewis may have been murdered because of his suspected consensual sexual relationship with 22-year-old Anna Davis. Davis and her husband were never tried, possibly for fear of a "mixed race relationship" scandal.
Over 100 people petitioned Gov. [[Richard Irvine Manning III|Richard Manning]] to commute the brothers' sentence. The signatories included prominent people including [[Blackstock, South Carolina|Blackstock's]] mayor, a sheriff, two trial jurors and the grand jury foreman. Nevertheless, the brothers were sent to the electric chair.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2010066394_pardon15.html?syndication=rss |title=Radio host Tom Joyner clears his family's name |newspaper=The Seattle Times |date=2009-10-15 |first=Seanna |last=Adcox |accessdate=2009-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604110034/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2010066394_pardon15.html?syndication=rss |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Thomas and Meeks Griffin were pardoned by the governor of South Carolina in October 2009. [[Tom Joyner]] had achieved the pardons after investigating the case and presenting evidence of the injustice, when he learned about the fate of his great-uncles.<ref name=tg>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6366628/South-Carolina-pardons-black-brothers-convicted-of-1913-killing.html | title=South Carolina pardons black brothers convicted of 1913 killing | newspaper=The Telegraph | date=2009-10-18 | location=London | first=Alex | last=Spillius | accessdate=2009-10-18 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527130608/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6366628/South-Carolina-pardons-black-brothers-convicted-of-1913-killing.html | archivedate=May 27, 2010 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1913 |rowspan="2" |[[Leo Frank]] |Murder of Mary Phagan |[[Marietta, Georgia]] |Death, later commuted |2 years; killed by lynch mob |Posthumously pardoned |- |colspan=5|Frank was a Jewish-American factory superintendent who was convicted in 1913 of the murder of a 13-year-old, female employee. He was taken from prison and lynched after his death sentence was commuted by the governor of Georgia to life in prison. In the late 20th century, Frank was posthumously pardoned by the state. |- |rowspan="2" |1916 |rowspan="2" |[[Thomas Mooney]] |Preparedness Day Bombing |[[San Francisco]], California |Death |22 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Mooney filed a writ of ''[[habeas corpus]]'' which was heard by the [[United States Supreme Court]] in 1937. Even though he presented evidence that his conviction was obtained through the use of [[perjury|perjured]] testimony and that the prosecution had suppressed favorable evidence, his writ was denied because he had not first filed a writ in state court. His case is important because it helped establish that a conviction based upon false evidence violates [[due process]]. Mooney was pardoned in 1939 by Governor [[Culbert Olson]]. |}
==1920s== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of crime ! Defendant(s) ! Crime ! Location ! Sentence ! Time served ! Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |1920 | rowspan="2" |[[Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti]] | Murders of Alessandro Berardelli and Frederick Parmenter during an armed robbery | [[Braintree, Massachusetts]] | Death | Executed | No |- |colspan=5| In 1977, as the 50th anniversary of the executions approached, Massachusetts Governor [[Michael Dukakis]] asked the Office of the Governor's Legal Counsel to report on "whether there are substantial grounds for believing—at least in the light of the legal standards of today—that Sacco and Vanzetti were unfairly convicted and executed" and to recommend appropriate action.<ref>"Report to the Governor in the Matter of Sacco and Vanzetti", July 13, 1977, in Upton Sinclair, ''Boston: A Documentary Novel'' (Cambridge, MA: Robert Bentley, Inc., 1978), 757-90, quote 757</ref> The resulting "Report to the Governor in the Matter of Sacco and Vanzetti" detailed grounds for doubting that the trial was conducted fairly in the first instance, and argued as well that such doubts were reinforced by "later-discovered or later-disclosed evidence."<ref>"Report to the Governor" (1977), 761</ref> The report questioned prejudicial cross-examination that the trial judge allowed, the judge's hostility, the fragmentary nature of the evidence, and eyewitness testimony that came to light after the trial. It found the judge's charge to the jury troubling for the way it emphasized the defendants' behavior at the time of their arrest and highlighted certain physical evidence that was later called into question.<ref>"Report to the Governor" (1977), 761-9</ref>
The report also dismissed the argument that the trial had been subject to judicial review, noting, "the system for reviewing murder cases at the time ... failed to provide the safeguards now present."<ref>"Report to the Governor" (1977), 768-73</ref> Based on recommendations of the Office of Legal Counsel, Dukakis declared August 23, 1977, the 50th anniversary of their execution, as Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti Memorial Day.<ref>"Proclamation by the Governor" (1977), 797-9; also included in Young and Kaiser, 3-4, and Tropp, 182-4.</ref> His proclamation, issued in English and Italian, stated that Sacco and Vanzetti had been unfairly tried and convicted, and that "any disgrace should be forever removed from their names."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1977/07/19/archives/around-the-nation-2d-group-of-city-workers-goes-on-strike-in.html "Massachusetts Admits Sacco-Vanzetti Injustice"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106055423/http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30C13FC3A5E16738DDDA00994DF405B878BF1D3& |date=November 6, 2012 }}, ''The New York Times'', July 19, 1977, accessed June 2, 2010</ref><ref name=icue>iCue: [http://icue.nbcunifiles.com/icue/files/icue/site/pdf/1514.pdf "Governor Dukakis Discusses Impending Exoneration of Sacco and Vanzetti", Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |March 23, 1944 |rowspan="2" |[[George Stinney]] |Murder of Betty June Binnicker, age 11, and Mary Emma Thames, age 8 |[[Alcolu, South Carolina]] |Death by electric chair |Executed |Yes |- |colspan=5|Stinney, who was black, was convicted by an [[all-white jury]] of the [[first-degree murder]] of two pre-teen white girls. No [[physical evidence]] existed in the case, and the sole evidence against Stinney was the [[circumstantial evidence|circumstantial]] fact that the girls had spoken with Stinney and his sister shortly before their murder. Three police officers claimed that Stinney had confessed to the murders. At age 14, he was the youngest person to be sentenced to death and executed in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |author=Snejana Farberov |title=Was the youngest person ever executed in the US innocent? Lawyers seek retrial in 1944 case of boy, 14, convicted of killing as his family say he had an alibi |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2488141/South-Carolina-lawyers-seek-retrial-executed-George-Stinney-Jr-1944-case.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=November 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140116041522/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2488141/South-Carolina-lawyers-seek-retrial-executed-George-Stinney-Jr-1944-case.html |archivedate=January 16, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="jones">{{cite book|last=Jones|first=Mark R.|title=South Carolina Killers: Crimes of Passion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5YdF1MePkfoC&pg=PA38 |year=2007 |publisher=The History Press |isbn=978-1-59629-395-3 |pages=38–42 |chapter=Chapter Five: Too Young to Die: The Execution of George Stinney, Jr. (1944) |accessdate=November 24, 2014}}</ref> On December 17, 2014, Stinney's conviction was vacated by [[circuit court]] judge Carmen Mullen, effectively clearing his name.<ref name="exoneration">{{cite news | url=http://www.wistv.com/story/27651255/george-stinney-14-year-old-convicted-of-44-murder-exonerated | date=December 17, 2014 | title=George Stinney, 14-year-old convicted of '44 murder, exonerated | publisher=''[[WIS]] TV'' | accessdate=December 17, 2014 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223031/http://www.wistv.com/story/27651255/george-stinney-14-year-old-convicted-of-44-murder-exonerated | archivedate=March 3, 2016 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> |}

Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |1961, June 3 |rowspan="2" |[[Clarence Earl Gideon]] |Breaking and Entering, Petty Theft |[[Bay Harbor, Florida]] |5 years in prison |2 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Gideon had been denied an attorney at the time of his first trial. At the time, the state of Florida did not have public defenders in all judicial circuits and the law did not require the court to appoint an attorney to the indigent. After conviction, he handwrote a petition for [[certiorari|writ of ''certiorari'']] to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]]. The justices considered the matter as ''[[Gideon v. Wainwright]]'' and ruled unanimously that Gideon's rights had been violated. When he was retried with a defense attorney, it was determined that the primary prosecution witness had committed the crime. The case inspired the book ''[[Gideon's Trumpet]]'' and a film adaptation by the same name. |- |rowspan="2" |1966, June 17 |rowspan="2" |[[Rubin Carter]] |Murder of James Oliver, Fred Nauyoks, and Hazel Tanis |[[Paterson, New Jersey]] |Life in prison |19 years |No |- |colspan=5|Carter was a professional [[boxer]] who was twice convicted of this triple murder, along with his friend and fellow defendant John Artis. Carter's second conviction was overturned in 1985. Carter inspired the 1975 [[Bob Dylan]] song "[[Hurricane (Bob Dylan song)|Hurricane]]", and the film ''[[The Hurricane (1999 film)|The Hurricane]]'' (1999) was based on his case. |- |rowspan="2" |1967, October 25 |rowspan="2" |[[James Joseph Richardson]] |Murder of his seven children by pesticide poisoning |[[Arcadia, Florida]] |Death |21 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|James Richardson was convicted of poisoning his children and received the death penalty.<ref name=Sentinel>{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Constance|title=State Won't Retry Richardson Murder Case|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1989-05-06/news/8905065202_1_james-richardson-reece-retry|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=May 6, 1989|accessdate=April 22, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130918184758/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1989-05-06/news/8905065202_1_james-richardson-reece-retry |archivedate=September 18, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Authorities believe that it is likely that a neighbor, Bessie Reece, committed the murders. After she developed [[Alzheimer's disease]], she confessed more than 100 times to the murders of these children to her caregivers at the nursing home.<ref name=Sentinel /><ref name=Herald /> At the time of the crime, Reece was on [[parole]] after being convicted of the poisoning death of her late husband.<ref name=Herald /> Reece was not investigated thoroughly at the time, although she was the last known person to see the children alive, and the last to feed them. She had at first denied going into their apartment.<ref name=Sentinel /><ref name=Herald>{{cite news|last=Herald Staff|title=Delayed Justice|newspaper=The Miami Herald|date=December 13, 1988 }}</ref> |}

''Daily Utah Chronicle'', February 9, 2011. In 2010, Bright joined [[Innocence Project]] New Orleans as Assistant Education and Outreach Director.<ref>Innocence Project New Orleans [http://ip-no.org/staff Staff Directory] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113091529/http://www.ip-no.org/staff |date=November 13, 2011 }}. Despite an alibi, Tibbs was convicted on the basis of a false eyewitness identification and an alleged confession to a fellow inmate.<ref name=Weber>{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Bruce|title=Delbert Tibbs, Who Left Death Row and Fought Against It, Dies at 74|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/08/us/delbert-tibbs-who-left-death-row-and-fought-against-it-dies-at-74.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|date=December 7, 2013|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215142300/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/08/us/delbert-tibbs-who-left-death-row-and-fought-against-it-dies-at-74.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|archivedate=December 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2011, Tibbs was instrumental in the decision of Governor [[Pat Quinn (politician)|Pat Quinn]] to repeal the death penalty in Illinois.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cjbk.com/InternationalNews/Article.aspx?id=262592 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719123048/http://www.cjbk.com/InternationalNews/Article.aspx?id=262592 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-19 |title=News/Talk 1290 CJBK London :: International News Story - Article |publisher=CJBK |date= |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://wjbc.com/ex-death-row-inmates-urge-quinn-to-sign-ban/ |title=Ex-death row inmates urge Quinn to sign ban |publisher=WJBC |date=2011-02-15 |accessdate=2012-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308143650/http://wjbc.com/ex-death-row-inmates-urge-quinn-to-sign-ban/ |archivedate=March 8, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Quinn signs bill repealing Illinois death pe11nalty |url=http://www.suntimes.com/4225981-417/quinn-signs-bill-repealing-illinois-death-penalty.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313095923/http://www.suntimes.com/4225981-417/quinn-signs-bill-repealing-illinois-death-penalty.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 13, 2011 |newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times |date= |accessdate=2012-09-01 |df= }}</ref> |-- | rowspan="2" |1974, May 15 | rowspan="2" |[[Murders of Rhonda Johnson and Sharon Shaw|Michael Lloyd Self]] | [[Murders of Rhonda Johnson and Sharon Shaw]] | [[Galveston, Texas]] |Life imprisonment | Life |No |- |colspan=5|Teenagers Rhonda Johnson and Sharon Shaw disappeared while at a beach in Galveston, Texas, on August 4, 1971; their remains were found in a marsh in January 1972. Though Michael Lloyd Self, a local [[sex offender]], wrote a confession, he contended that police officers forced him to do so at gunpoint. Self was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1975. In 1976, two of the officers who took his confession were arrested for numerous bank robberies and sentenced to 30–50 years. In 1998, Edward Howard Bell, a convicted [[serial killer]], admitted to the murders of Johnson and Shaw, though no direct connection could be made. Self died in prison in 2000 of cancer. Numerous investigators, a Galveston police officer, and a former [[Harris County, Texas|Harris County]] prosecutor all protested Self's conviction.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/09/29/elderly-inmate-claims-to-have-committed-nearly-dozen-murders.html|publisher=Fox News|title=Elderly Inmate Claims to Have Committed Nearly a Dozen Murders|author=The Associated Press|date=September 29, 2011|accessdate=November 28, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129151223/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/09/29/elderly-inmate-claims-to-have-committed-nearly-dozen-murders.html|archivedate=November 29, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1975 |rowspan="2" |[[Ricky Jackson, Ronnie Bridgeman, and Wiley Bridgeman]] |Murder of Harold Franks |[[Cleveland]], Ohio |Death |39 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Jackson and both the Bridgeman brothers were convicted and sentenced to death for the killing of Harold Franks, a [[money order]] salesman, based on the evidence of a 12-year-old boy, Eddie Vernon, who claimed to have seen them attack Franks. There were no other witnesses nor evidence linking the accused to the crime. In a signed affidavit in 2014, Vernon recanted, saying he had been coerced by the police. Jackson had escaped the death sentence because of a paperwork error. The sentences of the Bridgemans had been commuted to life. Jackson and Wiley Bridgeman were held in prison longer than any other persons who had been exonerated. Ronnie Bridgeman had been paroled after serving 28 years.<ref name=39years>{{cite news|last1=Skinner|first1=Curtis|title=Ohio man cleared of murder after 39 years in jail to get $1 million: newspaper|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/crime/ohio-man-cleared-of-murder-after-39-years-in-jail-to-get-dollar1-million-newspaper/ar-BBitpz2?ocid=ansnewsreu11|agency=Reuters|date=March 20, 2015|accessdate=March 22, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150322131740/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/crime/ohio-man-cleared-of-murder-after-39-years-in-jail-to-get-dollar1-million-newspaper/ar-BBitpz2?ocid=ansnewsreu11|archivedate=March 22, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> All three men received compensation and settlements from the state for their wrongful convictions and imprisonment. |-- |rowspan="2" |July 1976 |rowspan="2" |[[Lewis Fogle]] |Rape and murder of Deann Katherine Long |[[Indiana County, Pennsylvania]] |Life without parole |34 years |No |- |colspan=5|Fogle was convicted in 1982 of raping and killing 15-year-old Deann Katherine Long, who had died in 1976. DNA tests on the [[semen]] in the girl's body proved he was not the rapist. In August 2015, a senior judge vacated his conviction. The local district attorney joined in the motion to vacate his conviction, and Fogle was released.<ref name=Fogle>{{cite news|last1=Fuoco|first1=Michael A.|title=After 34 years in prison Indiana County man freed thanks to DNA evidence|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/east/2015/08/13/DNA-evidence-results-in-vacation-of-conviction-in-Indiana-County-murder-case/stories/201508130176|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=August 13, 2015|accessdate=August 15, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150815212434/http://www.post-gazette.com/local/east/2015/08/13/DNA-evidence-results-in-vacation-of-conviction-in-Indiana-County-murder-case/stories/201508130176|archivedate=August 15, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1976, November 27 |rowspan="2" |[[Randall Dale Adams]] |Murder of Robert W. Wood |[[Dallas]], Texas |Death |12 years |No |- |colspan=5|Adams was convicted of killing Dallas police officer Robert Wood. In 1988, the film ''[[The Thin Blue Line (1988 film)|The Thin Blue Line]]'', which was based on the case, was released. Public outcry over the film prompted officials to re-examine the case. Adams was released in 1989.<ref name=Martin>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Douglas|title=Randall Adams, 61, Dies --freed with the help of film|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/us/26adams.html|date=June 25, 2011|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830192927/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/26/us/26adams.html|archivedate=August 30, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1977 |rowspan="2" |[[Dewey Bozella]] |Murder of Emma Kapser |[[Poughkeepsie, New York]] |20 years to life |26 years |No |- |colspan=5|Bozella was accused of killing 92-year-old Emma Kapser. He was convicted on the basis of testimony from two jailhouse informants. [[DNA testing]] was not available because evidence from the crime had been destroyed post-conviction.<ref name=Duran>{{cite news|last1=Duran|first1=Amber|title=Wrongly imprisoned: Dewey Bozella tells MSU of his time in Sing Sing prison|url=http://www.the-standard.org/news/wrongly-imprisoned-dewey-bozella-tells-msu-of-his-time-in/article_df1e41d2-b6bc-11e2-bff3-001a4bcf6878.html|newspaper=The Standard|date=May 7, 2013}}</ref> Bozella's first conviction was overturned because the prosecutor removed all [[African Americans]] from the jury. He was tried again in December 1990. At the second trial, one witness recanted his prior statements, but Bozella was convicted a second time. The other witness later recanted. In addition, the defense later learned that the prosecution failed to turn over [[exculpatory evidence]] to the defense, including a fingerprint recovered from the scene that was linked to a felon. In 2009, Bozella's conviction was overturned and all charges were dropped.<ref name=Bozella>{{cite web|title=Dewey Bozella|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3038|publisher=The national registry of exonerations|accessdate=June 22, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903070158/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3038|archivedate=September 3, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" |March 14, 1977 |rowspan="2" |[[Brian Baldwin]] |Murder of Naomi Rolin |Monroe, Alabama |Death |Executed |No |- |colspan=5|Naomi Rolin was a white girl of 16 who was raped and murdered. Ed Horsely confessed to the murder, which he said he alone had committed, and was executed. But the police charged Baldwin with the murder based on his confession, which Baldwin said was extracted under beatings and an electric [[cattle prod]]. No forensic evidence connected Baldwin with the crime. The murder was committed by a left-handed person whereas Baldwin was right-handed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/jun/20/davidrose.theobserver|title=Death of justice in Alabama|last=Rose|first=David|date=1999-06-19|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-14|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826071009/https://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/jun/20/davidrose.theobserver|archivedate=August 26, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> All evidence was lost or destroyed after the execution. |-- |rowspan="2" |1977, July 9 |rowspan="2" |[[Gary Dotson]] |Rape of [[Cathleen Webb]] |[[Chicago]], Illinois |25 to 50 years' imprisonment for rape, 25 to 50 aggravated kidnapping to be served concurrently |approximately 6 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Sixteen-year-old Cathleen Crowell Webb made up a rape allegation to explain to her [[foster parent]]s her pregnancy concerns after having had [[consent#Sexual activity|consensual sex]] with her boyfriend the previous day. After a religious conversion, Webb confessed to her pastor that she had wrongly accused Dotson and began efforts to get him released. The prosecution refused to take any action, so they went to the media. The resulting public sympathy led the authorities to review the case. Eventually Dotson was cleared via DNA testing and released. |- |rowspan="2" |1978, May 11 |rowspan="2" |[[The Ford Heights Four]], Verneal Jimerson, Dennis Williams, Kenneth Adams and Willie Rainge |Rape of Carol Schmal and murder of Schmal and Lawrence Lionberg |[[Ford Heights, Illinois]] |Death for Jimerson and Williams, 75 years for Adams, and life for Rainge |18 years for Williams, Adams and Rainge. 11 years for Jimerson |Yes |- |colspan=5|The Ford Heights Four were convicted based on false forensic testimony, [[coercion]] of a prosecution witness, perjury by another witness who had an incentive to lie, and prosecution and police misconduct. Witness and DNA evidence uncovered in an investigation by three female journalism students at [[Northwestern University]] cleared the Ford Heights Four and led to the arrest and conviction of the real killers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.northwestern.edu/magazine/northwestern/spring99/trio.htm|title=Trio of Angels, Three students help free four death row inmates.|last=L. A.|first=|date=Spring 1999|work=Northwestern University Magazine|access-date=2016-10-01|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027045241/http://www.northwestern.edu/magazine/northwestern/spring99/trio.htm|archivedate=October 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1978, August 31 |rowspan="2" |[[Joseph Sledge]] |Murder of Josephine and Aileen Davis |[[Elizabethtown, North Carolina]] |Two consecutive life sentences |36 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Sledge escaped from prison during a four-year sentence for misdemeanor larceny and was recaptured days later. During this time, two women were killed in their home in Elizabethtown, North Carolina. Sledge was convicted of murdering the two women based on the testimony of two inmates who claimed that Sledge had admitted to the crime while in prison the next year. One of the informants later recanted his testimony, saying that he had lied due to police coercion and a reward of early parole and $3,000 prize money. The other informant received similar special treatment. [[Mitochondrial DNA]] testing of hairs found at the crime scene believed to be from the killer did not match Sledge, and he was declared innocent in January 2015. He had served more than 36 years for the crime.<ref name=NROEJS>{{cite web | title = National Registry of Exonerations: Joseph Sledge | url = http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4627 | publisher = [[Michigan Law School]] | date = January 23, 2015 | accessdate = February 20, 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150218105225/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4627 | archivedate = February 18, 2015 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1978, November 11 |rowspan="2" |[[Richard Coley]] |Murder of Rhonda and Donald Wicht |[[Simi Valley, California]] |Life without parole |39 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Coley was convicted of the murder of 24-year-old Rhonda Wicht and her 4-year-old son Donald Wicht in 1978. DNA tests not available at the time of his trial later showed Coley could not have done the murders, and DNA from others was present. She was tried and convicted of first degree murder. While in prison, she gave birth to a second son named DJ who was immediately placed in [[foster care]]. DJ was soon diagnosed with a disease called [[methylmalonic acidemia]], a condition that presents with symptoms very similar to antifreeze poisoning. Upon reinvestigation, it was discovered that the lab that tested Ryan's blood mistook the [[propionic acid]] in the sample for ethylene glycol, since their peaks are very close on the gas chromatograph printout. A professor with [[St. Louis University]] saw the case featured on ''[[Unsolved Mysteries]]'' and did an experiment where he sent blood samples containing propionic acid to a group of commercial labs. Almost half identified the sample as containing ethylene glycol. The prosecution charged that the fire was caused by [[arson]]. He has not been posthumously exonerated, but the case has gained widespread attention as a possible case of wrongful execution. A number of arson experts have decried the results of the original investigation as faulty. In June 2009, five years after Willingham's execution, the State of Texas ordered a re-examination of the case. Dr. Craig Beyler found "a finding of arson could not be sustained". Beyler said that key testimony from a fire marshal at Willingham's trial was "hardly consistent with a scientific mind-set and is more characteristic of mystics or psychics".<ref name=Grann>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/09/07/090907fa_fact_grann|title=Trial by Fire: Did Texas execute an innocent man?|first=David|last=Grann|authorlink=David Grann|magazine=[[The New Yorker]]|date=September 7, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110806070359/http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/09/07/090907fa_fact_grann|archivedate=August 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Beyler">{{cite web|title=Analysis of the Fire Investigation Methods and Procedures Used in the Criminal Arson Cases Against Ernest Ray Willis and Cameron Todd Willingham |first=Craig L. |last=Beyler |url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/document-preview.aspx?doc_id=10401390 |publisher=Hughes Associates, Inc. |date=August 17, 2009 |accessdate=September 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208111249/http://www.docstoc.com/docs/document-preview.aspx?doc_id=10401390 |archivedate=February 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The Texas Forensic Science Commission was scheduled to discuss the report by Beyler at a meeting on October 2, 2009, but two days before the meeting Texas Governor [[Rick Perry]] replaced the chair of the commission and two other members. Jones' conviction was eventually overturned by the [[Louisiana Supreme Court]], and all charges against him were subsequently dropped. |- |rowspan="2" |1992, August 17 |rowspan="2" |[[Juan Rivera (wrongful conviction)|Juan Rivera]] |Murder of 11-year-old Holly Staker |[[Waukegan, Illinois]] |Life in prison |20 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Rivera was wrongfully convicted three times for the murder of Staker, who was babysitting at a neighbor's house when she was raped and murdered by an intruder. Swabs were taken of a semen sample, but DNA testing was not performed at the time. Rivera was convicted on the basis of a confession that he claims was given under duress and which contained many factual inconsistencies. He was convicted twice before DNA testing was performed on the swabs taken from the crime scene. DNA testing excluded Rivera from being the source of the semen. Prosecutors decided to try him again despite the results of the DNA test, arguing that the semen sample was from consensual sex prior to the murder. He was convicted a third time.
His case was overturned a third and final time with the appellate court heavily criticizing prosecutors for arguing that Holly was sexually active without evidence and for putting so much weight on a confession obtained while Rivera, who suffered from mental illness, was in an "acute [[psychotic]] state" and which contained so many inaccuracies.
Following his exoneration, his defense team sought to do further testing on shoes that the state had once sought to enter into evidence. Holly's blood was found on shoes worn by Juan. The evidence had been dropped once it was discovered that the shoes were not for sale anywhere in the US until after the murder. Genetic testing performed in 2014 found not only Holly's blood, but genetic material that matches the semen found at the crime scene. His defense team argued that the reasonable interpretation is that in an effort to plant blood on Juan's shoes, the state also planted DNA from Holly's real killer. Following this revelation, the state agreed to settle with Rivera, giving him a $20 million USD settlement, the largest wrongful conviction settlement in US history.
The source of the DNA has never been identified, but it has been linked to evidence found at another murder scene. The man convicted of that murder insists this is proof that he himself has been wrongfully convicted. |-- |rowspan="2" |1993, April 8 |rowspan="2" |[[Gary Gauger]] |Murder of his parents, Morris and Ruth Gauger |[[McHenry County, Illinois]] |Death penalty |3 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Following the murder, police interrogated Gauger for 18 hours. Detectives lied to Gauger, claiming they had found blood-soaked clothes in Gauger's bedroom and that he had failed a [[polygraph]] test. Gauger was instructed to discuss a hypothetical situation and describe how he would have killed his parents during a possible alcohol-induced blackout. The interrogation was not tape-recorded and Gauger did not sign a confession. His hypothetical statements were later used in court in support of a claim that Gauger confessed to the crime. In 1996, he was granted an appeal and his alleged confession was thrown out. Without that evidence they were forced to drop the charges. James Schneider and Randall E. Miller, members of the [[Outlaws Motorcycle Club]], were later convicted of the murders. Gauger was pardoned in 2002.<ref name=Gauger>{{cite web|title=Gary Gauger|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3234|publisher=The national registry of exonerations|accessdate=June 21, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903063118/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3234|archivedate=September 3, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1993, February 13 |rowspan="2" |[[Lynn DeJac]] |Murder of her daughter Crystallynn Girard* |[[Buffalo, New York]] |25 years |14 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Lynn DeJac summoned police to her home on February 13, 1993, after finding her daughter, Crystallyn Girard, dead in her bed. DeJac told police that she spent the evening out with her boyfriend, Dennis Donohue, with whom she had had an argument that evening. The coroner ruled that she died from [[strangulation]]. Donohue became a suspect for a brief time after DeJac told police he may have returned to her house while she was out. He was arrested, but was later granted full immunity in return for testimony regarding DeJac's use of [[cocaine]] that evening. Wayne Hudson, a childhood friend of DeJac, claimed that DeJac confessed to him that she had killed her daughter. She was convicted on the basis of the testimony from the two men. At the time he came forward, Hudson was facing [[forgery]] charges and a possible life sentence in prison as a [[repeat offender]]. In 2008, a new autopsy determined that Crystallyn died of a cocaine overdose, not strangulation.<ref name=DeJac>{{cite web|title=Lynn DeJac|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3169|publisher=National Registry of Exonerations|accessdate=August 24, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826113723/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3169|archivedate=August 26, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" |1993, August 29 |rowspan="2" |[[Mark Maxson]] |Murder of six-year-old boy Lindsay Murdock |[[Chicago]], Illinois |Life plus 40 years |23 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Police subjected Maxson to torture and beatings until he made a confession to the murder of Lindsay Murdoch. In spite of withdrawing his confession and lack of physical evidence against him, Maxson was convicted and sentenced to life plus 40 years. In 2015 the Cook County Conviction Integrity Unit got DNA testing done which proved another man, Osborne Wade, had committed the murder. Wade confessed to the murder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://usa-general.com/chicago/accused-killer-wrote-to-boy-and-039;s-family-wrongly-convicted-man.html|title=Accused killer wrote to boy's family, wrongly convicted man|last=|first=|date=2016-09-30|publisher=USA General|access-date=2016-10-01|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002103436/http://usa-general.com/chicago/accused-killer-wrote-to-boy-and-039;s-family-wrongly-convicted-man.html|archivedate=October 2, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1994, April 30 |rowspan="2" |[[Ken Wyniemko]] |Criminal Sexual Conduct, Armed Robbery, Breaking and Entering |Clinton, Michigan |40–60 years |8 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Wyniemko was convicted on the basis of his resemblance to the composite sketch and identification of Wyniemko in a lineup by the victim. He was later cleared by DNA testing.<ref name=Wyniemko>{{cite web|title=Kenneth Wyniemko|url=http://www.innocenceproject.org/Content/Kenneth_Wyniemko.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627041024/http://www.innocenceproject.org/Content/Kenneth_Wyniemko.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 27, 2010|publisher=Innocence Project|accessdate=August 23, 2014}}</ref> |- |rowspan="2" |1995, March 2 |rowspan="2" |[[Shareef Cousin]] |Murder of Michael Gerardi |[[New Orleans]], Louisiana |Death |4 years |No |- |colspan=5|Cousin was convicted on the basis of an eyewitness identification by Gerardi's date. It was later discovered that she had made statements to police indicating that she wasn't wearing her glasses and didn't get a good look at the assailant. This statement was not disclosed to the defense. Another witness testified that he was coerced to testify against Cousin in exchange for a reduced sentence on his own charges.<ref name=Cousin>{{cite web|title=Shareef Cousin|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3126|publisher=The National Registry of Exonerations|accessdate=June 22, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903073858/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3126|archivedate=September 3, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> After his release, Cousin alleged that the prosecutor's office had illegally detained witnesses whom Cousin had planned to call to testify in his defense, making it impossible for them to testify.<ref name=Balko>{{cite news|last1=Balko|first1=Radley|title=The Untouchables: America's Misbehaving Prosecutors, and the System That Protects Them|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/prosecutorial-misconduct-new-orleans-louisiana_n_3529891.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=January 8, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114064840/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/prosecutorial-misconduct-new-orleans-louisiana_n_3529891.html|archivedate=January 14, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1995, April 14 (Discovered) |rowspan="2" |[[Alan Gell]] |Murder of Allen Ray Jenkins |[[Aulander, North Carolina]] |Death |9 years |No |- |colspan=5|Two 15-year-old girls testified that they were involved in a conspiracy involving Gell in exchange for a lower sentence. Gell was in prison or otherwise out of town for all but one day in April. Although the date of death is unknown, prosecutors hitched their timeline to that date. Gell's conviction was overturned after it was later discovered that prosecutors had withheld exculpatory evidence, including the testimony of 17 witnesses who said they had seen Jenkins alive after that date as well as a tape recording of one of the girls saying that she had to make up a story to tell the police. Gell was retried and acquitted of all charges.<ref name=Gell>{{cite web|title=Alan Gell|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3236|publisher=The national Registry of Exonerations|accessdate=June 21, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112205509/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3236|archivedate=November 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |1996 |rowspan="2" |[[Richard Alexander (exonerated convict)|Richard Alexander]] |Several rapes, dubbed "River Park Rapist" |[[South Bend, Indiana]] |20 years |5 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Alexander was convicted of a series of rapes in South Bend, Indiana, and was dubbed the "River Park Rapist". He was convicted largely on the basis of eyewitness testimony. In 2001, with Alexander already having served five years in prison, an alleged burglar and [[Child sexual abuse|child molester]] named Michael Murphy confessed to one of the two rapes of which Alexander had been convicted, knowing details only the true assailant would know.<ref name="ip">[http://www.innocenceproject.org/Content/48.php "Richard Alexander"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100812021712/http://www.innocenceproject.org/Content/48.php |date=August 12, 2010 }}. The [[Innocence Project]]. Retrieved December 27, 2006.</ref> With this revelation, a judge ordered a new round of DNA testing in Alexander's case. Hairs found at the scene of the rape were submitted to [[DNA profiling#Mitochondrial analysis|mitochondrial DNA testing]].<ref>Cultice, C. [http://www.export.gov/comm_svc/press_room/news/articles/reliagene_1003.html "Who Dunnit?: DNA Testing Exporter Helps Make the Case (or Not)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030459/http://www.export.gov/comm_svc/press_room/news/articles/reliagene_1003.html |date=September 27, 2007 }}. United States Government, [http://www.export.gov/ Export Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061228073019/http://www.export.gov/ |date=December 28, 2006 }}. Retrieved December 27, 2006.</ref> At the time of Alexander's original conviction, such testing was not available in the state of [[Indiana]]. The tests proved that the DNA did not match Alexander's profile, but did match Murphy's.<ref name="ip"/> Alexander was released from prison on December 12, 2001.<ref name="fof">Newton, M. (2004.) ''The Encyclopedia of High-Tech Crime and Crime-Fighting''. [[Checkmark Books]], an imprint of [[Facts on File, Inc.]]</ref> It is now believed that the River Park Rapist was actually two separate perpetrators. |-- |rowspan="2" |1998, June 7 |rowspan="2" |[[Clarence Elkins]] |Murder of Judith Johnson, Elkins' mother-in-law, rape of his niece Brooke |[[Barberton, Ohio]] |Life in prison |6.5 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Judith Johnson was beaten, raped and murdered while her 6-year-old granddaughter, Brooke, was staying at her house. Brooke was also beaten and raped, but survived. She told police that the killer "looked like Uncle Clarence". He was convicted on the basis of this identification. She later explained that she meant the killer resembled him, rather than being a positive identification and she felt pressured to testify against him at trial by the prosecutor. DNA testing performed after conviction from semen found on the victims excluded Elkins, but his appeal was denied. Elkins' wife, who is Judith's daughter, solved the case through her research. She identified Earl Mann, Johnson's neighbor, as a likely suspect. Elkins, who was in prison with Mann at the time, collected a cigarette butt from Mann. It was a match.<ref name=Elkins>{{cite web|title=Exoneration Case Detail - Clarence Elkins|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3202|publisher=The national registry of exonerations|accessdate=June 21, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715075124/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=3202|archivedate=July 15, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |}
==2000s== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Date of crime ! Defendant(s) ! Crime ! Location ! Sentence ! Time served ! Legally exonerated |- |-- |rowspan="2" |2000, September 28 |rowspan="2" |[[David Camm]] |Murder of his wife Kim and two children, Brad and Jill |Georgetown, Indiana |Life in prison |13 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|The key evidence against Camm was testimony regarding blood spatter patterns on his tee shirt. It was later discovered that one of the key prosecution witnesses, a blood spatter analyst whose findings had triggered the arrest, had falsified his credentials. He had testified at trial that he was a college professor in the process of getting his PhD. It was later uncovered that he had no affiliation to the university, had no training in blood spatter or crime scene analysis, and had never worked a single case prior to the Camm family murders. In 2013, he testified for the defense, explaining that he worked as an office assistant for a crime scene analyst and had been sent to the crime scene to take photos when he began voicing his opinions on the evidence. He claims the prosecutor, Stan Faith, fabricated the credentials for the trial.
A new suspect emerged when the defense compelled the prosecution to run DNA evidence found on a sweatshirt on the floor of the crime scene through [[CODIS]] a second time. It was discovered that the DNA was never run through CODIS despite the fact that Faith had assured Camm's defense team that it had been run and it returned no matches. The sweatshirt contained the DNA, prison nickname, and department of corrections number of Charles Boney, a convicted felon with a history of stalking and attacking women. He was on parole at the time for the attempted kidnapping of several college students from their apartment. Investigators had looked for Camm's DNA on the sweatshirt, but failed to investigate any other leads. A DNA analyst who worked on the case filed a complaint alleging that the prosecutor attempted to get her to testify that the foreign DNA sample was Camm's DNA. A fingerprint analyst who found Boney's prints testified to a similar interaction. The prosecutor was later discovered to be Boney's defense attorney as well as a personal family friend, and they admitted discussing the case prior to Boney becoming a suspect. Faith asserts this is coincidental and he did not know Boney was involved.<ref name=Camm>{{cite web|title=Exoneration case detail - David Camm|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4291|publisher=The national registry of exonerations|accessdate=June 21, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915182650/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4291|archivedate=September 15, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |2001, July 8 |rowspan="2" |[[Trials of Kirstin Lobato|Kirstin "Blaise" Lobato]] |Murder of Duran Bailey |[[Las Vegas, Nevada]] |40 to 100 years in prison |16 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|In May 2001, Lobato, then 18, was staying at a residential motel in Las Vegas when she was allegedly attacked by a black man who "smelled like alcohol and dirty diapers." She was able to escape after she pulled out a knife and slashed the man's groin. Lobato was addicted to [[meth]] and had not slept for three days at the time of the attack, so she did not report the event to police, but she did tell friends. One of the friends who heard Lobato's story told a teacher who notified police. In July, a homeless man named Duran Bailey was found murdered on the other side of town. His penis had been severed. Although Lobato told friends about her attack prior to Bailey's murder and she had an alibi for the time of the murder, police suspected Lobato to be his killer. Police confronted her about the attack and she tearfully told them details. At the end of the interview, she was informed that she killed the man who attacked her and she was charged with murder. This "confession" would serve as key evidence against her. It wasn't until after her arrest that she discovered that the man whose murder she was charged with wasn't the man who attacked her. In 2017, her defense team convinced the appellate court that had the jury heard the strong entomological evidence pinpointing of Bailey's time of death coupled with her alibi witnesses placing her in [[Panaca, Nevada]], they would have acquitted. Lobato's conviction was overturned. The district attorney took the further step of asking a judge to dismiss the case with prejudice, a move that bars her from ever being prosecuted for the crime.<ref name="Lobato">{{cite news|last1=Ferrara|first1=David|title=Judge tosses case against Kirstin Lobato, orders her freed|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/crime/courts/judge-tosses-case-against-kirstin-lobato-orders-her-freed/|agency=Las Vegas Review Journal|date=December 29, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230014540/https://www.reviewjournal.com/crime/courts/judge-tosses-case-against-kirstin-lobato-orders-her-freed/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Lobato2">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Jordan|title=How a rumor sent a teen to prison for murder in Vegas|url=https://theintercept.com/2015/03/12/murderinvegas/|agency=The intercept|date=March 12, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171227025634/https://theintercept.com/2015/03/12/murderinvegas/|archivedate=December 27, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Jordan">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Jordan|title=17 YEARS AFTER BEING CONVICTED OF A GRISLY MURDER IN VEGAS, KIRSTIN LOBATO SEES HER CHARGES DISMISSED|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/12/29/las-vegas-murder-kirstin-lobato-wrongful-conviction/|agency=The Intercept|date=December 29, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230021254/https://theintercept.com/2017/12/29/las-vegas-murder-kirstin-lobato-wrongful-conviction/|archivedate=December 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |-- |rowspan="2" |2001, November 1 |rowspan="2" |[[Ryan Ferguson (wrongful conviction)|Ryan Ferguson]] |Murder of Kent Heitholt |[[Columbia, Missouri]] |40 years in prison |9 years, 8 months |Yes |- |colspan=5|Ferguson, who was 17 at the time of the murder, was convicted on the basis of a friend's confession to police claiming he and Ferguson killed Heitholt for drinking money. His friend, Charles Erickson, had mental health issues and [[substance abuse]] issues at the time and initially claimed to have no memory of the evening. Ferguson's conviction was overturned on November 5, 2013, after it was uncovered that the prosecution withheld exculpatory evidence and the witnesses who testified against him recanted their testimony. Erickson remains incarcerated, but Ferguson has vowed to work to get him released. |-- |rowspan="2" |2002 |rowspan="2" |[[Brian Banks (American football)|Brian Banks]] |Rape of Wanetta Gibson* |[[Long Beach, California]] |6 years in prison |5 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Brian Banks was a student at [[Long Beach Polytechnic High School]] when a fellow student accused him of rape. He accepted a plea deal to avoid a lengthy sentence and ended up serving almost the entire sentence. The accuser was later recorded admitting that the sexual contact was consensual and that she made up the allegation so her mother wouldn't find out she was sexually active. Gibson's family had received a $1.5 million settlement from the school following Banks' guilty plea for failing to keep Wanetta safe. |-- |rowspan="2" |2008, September 21 |rowspan="2" |[[Adrian P. Thomas|Adrian Thomas]] |Murder of his son Matthew Thomas* |[[Troy, New York]] |25 years to life in prison |6 years |Yes |- |colspan=5|Four-month-old Matthew Thomas was rushed to the hospital by his father after finding him unresponsive. During the interrogation, investigators told him that it had been proven the child died from [[blunt force trauma]] and that they knew someone in the household had done it. They threatened to arrest his wife if he did not confess. He was convicted on the basis of his confession. It was later determined that the cause of death was [[sepsis]].<ref name=Thomas>{{cite web|title=Adrian Thomas|url=https://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4449|publisher=The National Registry of exonerations|accessdate=June 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903062500/http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4449|archivedate=September 3, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- |}

{{Orphan|date=February 2017}}
'''Pharmaceutical innovations''' are currently guided by a patent system,<ref>{{Cite book|title = Review of the Innovation Patent System|last = |first = |publisher = |year = 2014|isbn = 978-0-9804542-7-7|location = |pages = 2|url = http://www.acip.gov.au/pdfs/ACIP_Final_Report_-_Review_of_the_Innovation_Patent_System.pdf|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150227150807/http://www.acip.gov.au/pdfs/ACIP_Final_Report_-_Review_of_the_Innovation_Patent_System.pdf|archivedate = 2015-02-27|df = }}</ref> the patent system protects the innovator of medicines for a period of time. The patent system does not currently stimulate innovation or pricing that provides access to medicine for those who need it the most, It provides for profitable innovation.<ref>{{Citation|title = Medicine for the 99 percent|url = http://www.ted.com/talks/thomas_pogge_medicine_for_the_99_percent|accessdate = 2015-04-15|first = Thomas|last = Pogge}}</ref> As of 2014 about $140 Billion is spent on research and development of pharmaceuticals which produces 25-35 new drugs. Technology, which is transforming science, medicine, and research tools has increased the speed at which we can analyze data but we currently still must test the products which is a lengthy process.<ref name="Milet">{{Cite web|title = MedidataVoice: The Next Wave Of Pharmaceutical Innovation: An Interview With Bernard Munos|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/medidata/2014/10/06/the-next-wave-of-pharmaceutical-innovation-an-interview-with-bernard-munos/|accessdate = 2015-04-15|first = Sylvain|last = Milet}}</ref> Differences in the performance of medical care may be due to variation in the introduction and circulation of pharmaceutical innovations.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The timing of introduction of pharmaceutical innovations in seven European countries - Westerling - 2014 - Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice - Wiley Online Library|url = http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/jep.12122|journal = Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice|access-date = 2015-04-15|doi=10.1111/jep.12122|volume=20|pages=301–310}}</ref>
Pharmaceutical innovation may not apply the same definition of "initiative" as other industries because while a product might use a new molecule or formula, that by itself holds very little value. For people that need the product the health benefits that were not previously achievable may be a deciding factor as to whether or not it is initiative. While a pharmaceutical company may view a product that fills a niche as innovative if it can produce a profit.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Morgan|first1=Steven|last2=Lopert|first2=Ruth|last3=Greyson|first3=Devon|title=Toward a definition of pharmaceutical innovation|journal=Open Med|date=2008|pmc=3091590|pmid=21602949|volume=2|pages=e4–7}}</ref>
A decline in research and development has been coined as [[Eroom's Law]].<ref name=forbespp>{{cite news|last1=Feyman|first1=Yevgeniy|title=Is Pharmaceutical Productivity In Decline? Maybe Not|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2015/04/13/is-pharmaceutical-productivity-in-decline-maybe-not/|accessdate=16 April 2015|publisher=Forbes|date=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Eroom's Law in pharmaceutical R&D.|journal=Nature Reviews Drug Discovery|date=2012|doi=10.1038/nrd3681|volume=11|pages=191–200|pmid=22378269 | last1 = Scannell | first1 = JW | last2 = Blanckley | first2 = A | last3 = Boldon | first3 = H | last4 = Warrington | first4 = B}}</ref>
== Current Model == The FDA has implemented the Breakthrough Therapy Designation which should help bring new needed products to the market faster.<ref name="Milet"/>  One of the key concerns in the current patent system is that an innovation patent is overly generous given that it has a very low inventiveness threshold.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Review of the Innovation Patent System|url = http://www.acip.gov.au/pdfs/ACIP_Final_Report_-_Review_of_the_Innovation_Patent_System.pdf|website = www.acip.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-04-15|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150227150807/http://www.acip.gov.au/pdfs/ACIP_Final_Report_-_Review_of_the_Innovation_Patent_System.pdf|archivedate = 2015-02-27|df = }}</ref>
The '''[[Medicines Patent Pool]]''' (MPP), is a United Nations-backed organisation founded in July 2010<ref>http://www.unitaid.eu/images/EB11/05%20_eb11%20res.5%20implementation%20of%20patent%20pool.pdf{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and based in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. The MPP aims to improve access to appropriate, affordable HIV medicines and technologies for people living with HIV in developing countries. Working in partnership with a range of stakeholders, the MPP opens the door to generic low-cost production of key HIV therapies as well as fixed-dose combinations and paediatric formulations by creating a pool of relevant patents for sub-licensing and product development.<ref>{{cite web|last1=RUNYOWA|first1=TAVENGWA|title=Medicines Patent Pool Aims To Increase Access To HIV Drugs In Developing Countries|url=http://www.ip-watch.org/2011/03/10/medicines-patent-pool-aims-to-increase-access-to-hiv-drugs-in-developing-countries/|website=IP Watch|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
=== Measurement === Kristopher J. Hult has proposed a new measurement based on novel and incremental innovation. The model predicts a decline of 40% for the 2010s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hult|first1=Kristopher|title=Kristopher J. Hult: Research|url=http://home.uchicago.edu/~khult/research.html|website=University of Chicago - Department of Economics}}</ref>
One current way to measure is the [[Internal rate of return]], which is used to measure and compare the profitability of investments. [[Reuters]] used the method to measure 2012 and found that the rate fell from 7.7% to 7.2%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Measuring the return from pharmaceutical innovation 2012|url=http://thomsonreuters.com/en/articles/2013/measuring-return-from-pharmaceutical-innovation-2012.html|website=Reuters|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref>
=== Barriers === Regulatory uncertainty is one area that stifles innovation. The approval processes are becoming increasingly complex.<ref>{{Cite web|title = measuring the return from pharmaceutical innovation 2014|url = http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/life-sciences-health-care/measuring-the-return-from-pharmaceutical-innovation-2014.pdf|website = www2.deloitte.com|accessdate = 2015-04-15}}</ref>
== Proposed Models ==
The '''[[Health Impact Fund]]''' ('''HIF''') is a proposed pay-for-performance mechanism that would provide a market-based solution to problems concerning the development and distribution of medicines globally. It would incentivize the research and development of new pharmaceutical products that make substantial reductions in the global [[disease burden|burden of disease]]. The HIF is the creation of a team of researchers led by the [[Yale]] philosopher [[Thomas Pogge]] and the [[University of Calgary]] economist Aidan Hollis, and is promoted by the non-profit organization Incentives for Global Health (IGH).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hollis|first1=A|last2=Grootendorst|first2=P|last3=Levine|first3=DK|last4=Pogge|first4=T|last5=Edwards|first5=AM|title=New approaches to rewarding pharmaceutical innovation.|journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal|date=2011|doi=10.1503/cmaj.100375|pmid=21149519|pmc=3071389|volume=183|pages=681–5}}</ref>
